quiz.name: 2026 CFA Program LI Mock Exam A Session 2
quiz.subtopic: 2026 CFA Program LI Mock Exam A Session 2
instructions:
CFA Level 1 Mock Exam Instructions

This CFA Level I mock exam (Session 2) is in English and contains 90 multiple-choice questions. You will have 2 hours and 15 minutes to complete the exam and review your answers. 

Before You Begin

Please note the following in regards to this examination:

  • International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) apply unless otherwise noted.
  • "The Code" refers to the CFA Institute Code of Ethics.
  • "The Standards" refers to the CFA Institute Standards of Professional Conduct.
  • "GIPS® standards" refers to the Global Investment Performance Standards.

How to Answer Questions

  • Each question is numbered and includes multiple-choice options (lettered A, B, C).
  • For each question:
    • Decide which answer is best.
    • Select the corresponding letter.
    • Click 'Next' to move to the next question.
  • You may:
    • Select only one answer per question.
    • Skip questions or return to questions by selecting the ‘Previous’ or the ‘Next’ buttons.

After Completing the Exam

  • Click 'Submit' when you are finished.
  • Once submitted, you may review all questions and your selected answers.
  • Only selected responses will be scored.
  • Your score will reflect the number of correct answers only.
    • No penalty for incorrect answers.
    • It is to your advantage to answer every question, even if you are unsure of the correct answer.
  • If you finish early, use the remaining time to review questions you are unsure about.

Click the 'Begin' button when you are ready to start the mock exam.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.03-Deriv-Pitrakkou-05
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, counterparty credit risk of a forward contract is:

answerFeedback.3f1ecba7-b43f-4b71-896e-2723cf4a44fd: Correct because counterparty credit risk for forward contracts is higher as the MTM is not settled until maturity, giving rise to counterparty credit risk over time since no cash is exchanged from inception of the contract to its maturity or expiration. Futures contract prices fluctuate daily based upon market changes. The daily settlement mechanism resets the futures MTM to zero, and variation margin is exchanged to settle the difference, reducing counterparty credit risk.
answerFeedback.76a0a44e-e2f7-46c5-ab92-599069e07536: Incorrect because counterparty credit risk is greater for forward contracts because MTM is not settled until maturity, giving rise to counterparty credit risk over time since no cash is exchanged from inception of the contract to its maturity or expiration. Futures contract prices fluctuate daily based upon market changes. The daily settlement mechanism resets the futures MTM to zero, and variation margin is exchanged to settle the difference, reducing counterparty credit risk.
answerFeedback.ec9e8b21-302b-46a8-a71e-f932f36b9d7e: Incorrect because counterparty credit risk is greater for forward contracts because the MTM is not settled until maturity, giving rise to counterparty credit risk over time since no cash is exchanged from inception of the contract to its maturity or expiration. Futures contract prices fluctuate daily and the daily settlement mechanism resets the futures MTM to zero, and variation margin is exchanged to settle the difference, reducing counterparty credit risk.

choices.itemBody: A. less than the counterparty credit risk of a futures contract.
B. equal to the counterparty credit risk of a futures contract.
C. greater than the counterparty credit risk of a futures contract.

entry.title: ITEM_20170427068
entry.itemBody: At the first of the year, an investor decides to invest $1.5 million in a hedge fund with an incentive fee of 15% and a hard hurdle rate of 4%. At the end of the year, the fund has a return of 23.3%. The incentive fee payment that the general partner of the fund earned based on this client’s investment at the end of the year is closest to:

answerFeedback.2b53534a-bb79-4046-90f1-da0828b35ec1: Incorrect because the fee was calculated using an increased asset base as follows: 23.3% × $1.5 million = $349,500 and then taking a 15% incentive fee on this return: $349,500 × 15% = $52,425.
answerFeedback.95efff6e-6ec3-4c5e-a0a8-641fbdac290d: Incorrect because the fee was calculated using an increased investor asset base as follows: 23.3% × $1.5 million = $349,500 and then taking a 15% incentive fee on this return less a 4% hurdle rate: $349,500 × 15% – 4% = $38,445.
answerFeedback.f430449b-f31a-4b3f-8d4b-4bca7a6b519e: Correct because the investor’s return met the 4% hurdle rate, so the incentive fee charged would be ($1,849,500 – $1,500,000 – $60,000) × 15% = $43,425.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Barker-08
entry.itemBody: Over a given holding period, performance of credit-risky bonds will most likely benefit from:

answerFeedback.28f973ef-57cf-4198-a79a-7e7e339851b2: Incorrect because weakening economic conditions will push investors to desire a greater risk premium and drive overall credit spreads wider. Wider spreads hurt bond performance, whereas narrower spreads help bond performance.
answerFeedback.52ece2a7-33b2-4e97-965c-39d948e85f2a: Correct because in periods of high demand for bonds, spreads will move tighter. Wider spreads hurt bond performance, whereas narrower spreads help bond performance.
answerFeedback.cb450cba-d437-4fe0-80a6-4dfd30a10a2e: Incorrect because wider spreads hurt bond performance, whereas narrower spreads help bond performance.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-FI-Moustra-05
entry.itemBody: Which of the following securities is most likely subject to the highest prepayment risk?

answerFeedback.05dbe31a-d449-4821-91e0-cec5c997061c: Incorrect because for credit card receivable ABS, the collateral is a pool of non-amortizing loans. During the lockout period, the cash proceeds from principal repayments are reinvested in additional credit card receivables. During this period, there is no prepayment risk and potential default risk is generally limited or is absorbed by credit enhancements. When the lockout period is over, principal repayments are used to pay off the outstanding principal on the ABS.
answerFeedback.9bf0320f-25db-4043-ba08-cb07e0eb507a: Correct because ABS and MBS pass-through security cash flows are uncertain because scheduled and actual payments frequently differ. Borrower behavior, such as the early payment of interest and principal as well as payment delinquencies over the life of a loan, depends upon a number of factors, including the income of the borrower (household income or cash flows for a corporation), the terms and conditions of the loan (such as the original interest rate versus current rates and any prepayment penalties), and the sale of the underlying asset being financed. To correctly value these securities, investors make certain assumptions about the predicted contractual payments after factoring in prepayment risk. Prepayment risk is the risk that the principal or a proportion of the principal is paid back at a different pace from the contractually agreed scheduled payment plan by the borrower. Prepayment risk has two components: contraction risk and extension risk, both of which reflect changes in the general level of interest rates.
answerFeedback.e383f695-6cf2-45f7-b39d-4ab01bc16261: Incorrect because covered bonds usually consist of one bond class per cover pool. Another important feature lies in the dynamic nature of the cover pool. The assets in the pool are monitored by a third party for performance and adherence to underwriting standards. Moreover, the covered bond issuer must replace any prepaid or non-performing assets (i.e., assets that do not generate the promised cash flows) to ensure sufficient cash flows until the maturity of the covered bond.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.08-Deriv-Bangaruswamy-20
entry.itemBody: In the binomial option pricing model, if investors' risk aversion increases, the risk-neutral probability of an upward price movement in an underlying asset:

answerFeedback.2bba9a59-0947-4b76-ad42-173fc367ed59: Correct an option’s price is independent of investors’ risk aversion and the probability of the underlying price moving up (or down), due to the ability to construct a perfect hedge of the option using the underlying asset.
answerFeedback.668add5e-153c-4a1c-aa17-5dd0980f5bea: Incorrect an option’s price is independent of investors’ risk aversion and the probability of the underlying price moving up (or down), due to the ability to construct a perfect hedge of the option using the underlying asset.
answerFeedback.f626f48c-f640-4cd3-9db0-8f79ba67586e: Incorrect an option’s price is independent of investors’ risk aversion and the probability of the underlying price moving up (or down), due to the ability to construct a perfect hedge of the option using the underlying asset.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607025
entry.itemBody: If a bank wants the ability to retire debt prior to maturity in order to take advantage of lower borrowing rates, it most likely issues a:

answerFeedback.3f73f2be-bd74-430b-a752-fa5037357f89: Incorrect because putable bonds give bondholders the ability to sell the bond at predetermined price to issuers.
answerFeedback.89cc16cf-7686-44fc-9c3b-b10f611a8c03: Incorrect because convertible bonds give bondholders the ability to convert the bond to a predetermined number of shares of the company.
answerFeedback.acf7e872-be84-45df-bf47-52d89aa9efe1: Correct. Callable bonds give issuers the ability to retire debt prior to maturity. The most compelling reason for them to do so is to take advantage of lower borrowing rates.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08720
entry.itemBody: Companies issue equity securities for which of the following purpose(s)?

answerFeedback.3e478516-2744-4dcf-890d-705ac400891d: Incorrect because companies issue equity to both make acquisitions and ensure that debt covenants are met.
answerFeedback.450accf8-65bb-4603-82c9-99e6ef6eb2f9: Incorrect because companies issue equity to both make acquisitions and ensure that debt covenants are met.
answerFeedback.4d3d2bdd-be01-49ba-9eab-95f3d47fa341: Correct because companies issue equity to both make acquisitions and ensure that debt covenants are met.

choices.itemBody: B. Ensuring that debt covenants are met only
C. Both making acquisitions and ensuring that debt covenants are met

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Chan-14
entry.itemBody: To determine if an equity security is fairly valued, the security's market price is most likely compared to its:

answerFeedback.2475d005-ae97-400a-a364-35737f178634: Incorrect because by comparing estimates of intrinsic value and market price, an analyst can make a determination about value. The book value of a company’s equity—the difference between its total assets and total liabilities—increases when the company retains its net income.
answerFeedback.4ed549f9-ba38-4579-a771-65d3027f293a: Correct because by comparing estimates of intrinsic value and market price, an analyst can arrive at one of three conclusions: the security is undervalued, overvalued, or fairly valued in the marketplace.
answerFeedback.e891838f-3902-4fe2-a10e-fdceff82a78e: Incorrect because by comparing estimates of intrinsic value and market price, an analyst can make a determination about value. Par value is the principal amount, principal value, or simply the amount that the issuer agrees to repay bondholders on the maturity date.

entry.title: ITEM_20170427038
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements is most likely true regarding venture capital?

answerFeedback.28bdfafa-3b40-4877-98ff-3b88b10a1e04: Incorrect because the venture capital strategy typically invests in start-up or early stage companies, not later stage companies. Venture capital is a specialized form of private equity whereby ownership capital is used for non-public companies in the early life cycle or startup phase, where often an idea or business plan exists with a limited operation or customer base.
answerFeedback.72ab5bfd-6322-4c7f-89e5-8010b5b1006f: Incorrect because venture capital investments require long time horizons. Features that may distinguish alternative investments include illiquidity, long investment time horizons, and large capital outlays.
answerFeedback.d8e1e717-d496-4b2b-a81d-3f43f271a99d: Correct because investing in private equity, including venture capital, is riskier than investing in common stocks and requires a higher return for accepting its higher risk, including illiquidity and leverage risks.

choices.itemBody: A. Investors tend to have short time horizons
B. Investors require a higher return than investors in publicly traded equity
C. Investments typically are in later stage and more established companies

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Equity-Milosevic-10
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a market for a stock:

Best offer $48
Market bid–ask spread $2

If a new sell limit order is placed at $49, the limit order:

answerFeedback.3b6659ee-9c4c-47c9-b1a8-524dbebdb38f: Incorrect because the space between the current best bid and offer defines the inside of the market. A new limit order placed inside the market (between the best bid and offer) would make the market by improving the quoted prices. A candidate may incorrectly add the market bid–ask spread to the best offer and assume that a sell limit order at $49 is less than $50 and therefore makes the market.
answerFeedback.5338baee-4fb1-42a4-86f4-cd65f432aa65: Correct because a sell order placed above the best offer is behind the market. In this example the sell order [$49] is placed above the best offer [$48] and is therefore behind the market.
answerFeedback.f6a57226-ebe4-4366-8fc6-dd8efb6885ee: Incorrect because traders who offer to trade make a market. Those who trade with them take the market. Given the sell-order is behind the market there is no trade and thereby this order will not take the market. A candidate who confuses "bids" and "asks" may add market bid-ask spread to the best offer, instead of subtracting it. That is, $48 plus $2 to arrive at $50 and then the candidate incorrectly assumes that the sell-order at $49 will be executed and thereby takes the market.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-PM-Tsependa-03
entry.itemBody: With respect to risk management, risk budgeting applies to:

answerFeedback.6aeb8275-344b-4ab3-9504-1899f109ead4: Incorrect because risk budgeting applies to both business management and portfolio management, not only to business management.
answerFeedback.9cd3abe1-f4e9-445b-b0b4-ac914b1ea7aa: Correct because risk budgeting applies to both business management and portfolio management. Its foundation is the perspective that business or portfolio management involves assembling a number of risk activities or securities, which can be collated into an assemblage of various risk characteristics.
answerFeedback.9e1fcfbe-9e90-47f7-a293-0a40859bec66: Incorrect because risk budgeting applies to both business management and portfolio management, not only to portfolio management.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07582
entry.itemBody: If the Macaulay duration and time-to-maturity of a bond are equal, the bond is most likely a:

answerFeedback.2b1adc1f-095d-4d8a-bf7d-d26b6752569c: Incorrect because the Macaulay and modified yield duration statistics for a traditional fixed-rate bond are primarily functions of the bond’s features: its time-to-maturity, its coupon rate, its yield-to-maturity, and the fraction of the current coupon period that has elapsed. Thus for coupon bonds trading below par, at par, or above par, the relationship between Macaulay duration and time to maturity is not linear.
answerFeedback.78a20e7c-a781-446b-bc0a-15444eb3524e: Correct because zero-coupon bonds have a single payment, the face value at maturity, the present weighted-average time to receipt of cash flows is the same as the time-to-maturity because that single cash flow has a present value weight of 1.0. Therefore, the Macaulay duration of a zero-coupon bond is its time-to-maturity.
answerFeedback.e810ee75-be6b-4e57-88ae-7a791855b8a5: Incorrect because the Macaulay and modified yield duration statistics for a traditional fixed-rate bond are primarily functions of the bond’s features: its time-to-maturity, its coupon rate, its yield-to-maturity, and the fraction of the current coupon period that has elapsed. Thus for coupon bonds trading below par, at par, or above par, the relationship between Macaulay duration and time to maturity is not linear.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kashyap-17
entry.itemBody: If a semi-annual pay bond has a yield-to-maturity of 7.5%, the yield-to-maturity based on quarterly compounding is closest to:

answerFeedback.364f1c79-82f4-44a6-b95d-5700d6126393:
Incorrect because the formula converts from quarterly to semi-annual compounding:

(1 + (APR/2))42 = (1 + (APR/4))24 

(1 + (APR/2))42 = (1 + (0.075/4))24

APR ≠ 0.075703 ≈ 7.57%.
answerFeedback.3d411bae-26f7-4570-bd30-ff676b9d7d21:
Correct because the formula to convert from semi-annual to quarterly compounding is:

(1 + (APR/2))2 = (1 + (APR/4))4 

(1 + (0.075/2))2 = (1 + (APR/4))4

APR = 0.07431 ≈ 7.43%.
answerFeedback.c9548334-7cb0-4091-8201-f89f608d7673:
Incorrect because the formula converts from annual to quarterly compounding:

(1 + (APR/1))1 = (1 + (APR/4))4 

(1 + (0.75)) = (1 + (APR/4))4

APR ≠ 0.072978 ≈ 7.30%.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516010
entry.itemBody: A trader seeking to sell a very large block of stock for her client most likely executes the trade in a(n):

answerFeedback.645febc2-a65c-4807-9771-facf9c5303bb: Incorrect because an order-driven market follows an order matching system run by an exchange or a broker using rules to arrange trades submitted by traders.
answerFeedback.decfca24-c39f-40a1-89b6-aa55848bae65: Correct because instruments that are infrequently traded and expensive to carry as inventory (e.g., very large blocks of stock, real estate properties, fine art masterpieces, and liquor licenses) are executed in brokered markets. Organizing order-driven markets for such instruments is not sensible because too few traders would submit orders to them.
answerFeedback.e8ee9645-c550-43cf-a9f7-211e95bbe832: Incorrect because in quote-driven markets (also called price-driven, dealer, or OTC markets) customers trade with dealers, and the instruments traded are mostly bonds, currencies, and spot commodities.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-Kashyap-Clone02ofCFA-L1-00096
entry.itemBody:
An investor sells a European put option with the following characteristics:

Put price $40
Exercise price $1,500

If the price of the underlying at expiration is $1,550, the profit or loss for the seller is:

answerFeedback.16ba231e-6160-44bf-8aa2-0b877e6c5473: Incorrect because it represents the payoff to the call buyer cT = Max(0,ST – X), where ST is the price of the underlying at expiration and X is the exercise price. Therefore, cT = Max(0,(1,550 –1,500)) = 50. By contrast, to the put seller, the profit is Π = –Max(0,X – ST) + p0, where p0 is the put price. Therefore, Π = –Max(0,(1,500 – 1,550)) + 40 = 40.
answerFeedback.b542c152-2837-4a30-a574-26446db53e8c: Incorrect because it represents the put price p0 less the difference between the exercise price X and the price of the underlying ST at expiration: 40 – (1,550 – 1,500) = –10. This would be the profit to the seller of a call option, Π = –Max(0,ST – X) + c0, with the same exercise price and the same selling price. By contrast, to the put seller, the profit is Π = –Max(0,X – ST) + p0. Therefore, Π = –Max(0,(1,500 – 1,550)) + 40 = 40.
answerFeedback.de2f5100-ee81-47bd-a124-adf12b6df019: Correct because to the put seller, the profit is Π = –Max(0,X – ST) + p0, where X is the exercise price, ST is the price of the underlying at expiration, and p0 is the put price. Therefore, Π = –Max(0,(1,500 – 1,550)) + 40 = 40.

entry.title: ITEM_CopyofCFA-L1-06429
entry.itemBody: A convertible bond arbitrage hedge fund is most likely to focus on buying:

answerFeedback.34d1d693-22ba-4fac-bd9e-9d92806e4d9b: Incorrect because event-driven strategies seek to profit from defined catalyst events, typically involving changes in corporate structure, such as an acquisition or restructuring. Further subdivisions of this category by HFR includes  activist. The term “activist” is short for “activist shareholder.” Here, managers secure sufficient equity holdings to allow them to influence corporate policies or direction. They thus try to create business catalysts, moving the investment towards a desired outcome. Buying sufficient convertible bonds to influence company policies in the event the bonds are converted may well be a valid hedge fund strategy, but it is not the focus of a convertible bond arbitrage strategy.
answerFeedback.acf71001-5a6b-4d34-8984-9b687872891d: Correct because relative value funds seek to profit from a pricing discrepancy between related securities based on an unusual short-term relationship. The expectation is that the discrepancy will be resolved over time. An example of a relative value strategy is  convertible bond arbitrage. This conceptually market-neutral investment strategy seeks to exploit a perceived mispricing between a convertible bond and its component parts—namely, the underlying bond and the embedded stock option—relative to the pricing of a reference equity into which the bond may someday convert. The strategy typically involves buying convertible debt securities and simultaneously selling a certain amount of the same issuer’s common stock.
answerFeedback.fe8f8b24-5463-467a-b058-7a103c58ab73: Incorrect because event-driven strategies seek to profit from defined catalyst events, typically involving changes in corporate structure, such as an acquisition or restructuring. Further subdivisions of this category by HFR includes distressed/restructuring. These strategies focus on securities of companies either in or perceived to be near bankruptcy.

choices.itemBody: A. convertible bonds of companies at or near bankruptcy.
B. convertible bonds and selling the stock of the same company.
C. sufficient convertible bonds of a company in order to influence the company's policies.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B PM 04JRE
entry.itemBody:
A security and the market exhibit the following characteristics:

Risk-free rate of return 2%
Market risk premium 8%
Beta 1.5
Security's correlation with the market 0.5

Based on the CAPM, the security’s expected rate of return is closest to:

answerFeedback.26ee2c23-c295-48fb-afb8-f89a758d3810: Incorrect because it inputs the market risk premium as the expected return on the market in the CAPM calculation: E(Ri) = Rf + βi[E(Rm) – Rf]. Therefore, it incorrectly calculates expected return as 2% + (1.5) × (8% – 2%) = 11%.
answerFeedback.3ec21b1a-c846-42c4-a5de-8cf7da23aeae: Incorrect because it uses the security’s correlation with the market as the measurement for beta in the CAPM calculation: E(Ri) = Rf + βi[E(Rm) – Rf]. Therefore, it incorrectly calculates expected return as Rf + ρi,m × (market risk premium) = 2% + (0.5) × (8%) = 6%. The correlation metric is used to calculate beta, but it is not equal to beta.
answerFeedback.72c35e5e-2f2a-4bf7-abf8-2d8387de64c7: Correct because the calculation of the security’s expected return using the CAPM calculation is as follows: E(Ri) = Rf + βi[E(Rm) – Rf] = 2% + (1.5) × (8%) = 14%.  The market risk premium is the expected return minus the risk free rate so you do not need to subtract the risk free rate because it is already reflected in the market risk premium.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Equity-Bailey-10
entry.itemBody: A disadvantage of using price multiples to value stocks is that:

answerFeedback.482f0fdb-e352-435e-9b22-b7d2a56b0326: Correct because differences in reporting rules among different markets and in chosen accounting methods can result in revenues, earnings, book values, and cash flows that are not easily comparable.
answerFeedback.597f25db-a25d-4663-b89a-b18ae5bce0d0: Incorrect because the major advantage of using price multiples is that they allow for relative comparisons, both cross-sectional (versus the market or another comparable) and in time series.
answerFeedback.aa77c7f0-681b-4916-a0f0-021d1a3951aa: Incorrect because price multiples are popular with investors because the multiples can be calculated easily.

choices.itemBody: C. accounting methods produce different results that are not easily comparable across companies.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Moustra-18
entry.itemBody: Empirical duration:

answerFeedback.198c4719-dfe3-416c-a45a-7aead895be68: Correct because empirical duration uses statistical methods and historical bond prices to derive the price–yield relationship for specific bonds or bond portfolios.
answerFeedback.b03e8bd7-f973-4111-bb61-6821d662b793: Incorrect because the approach to estimate duration and convexity statistics using mathematical formulas is often referred to as analytical duration. These estimates of the impact of benchmark yield changes on bond prices implicitly assume that government bond yields and spreads are independent variables that are uncorrelated with one another. Analytical duration, not empirical duration, relies on this assumption.
answerFeedback.df3467ea-6b7e-4c97-a493-debd739c725a: Incorrect because the same macroeconomic factors driving government bond yields lower in a market stress scenario will cause high-yield bond credit spreads to widen because of an increase in expected default risk. Since credit spreads and benchmark yields are negatively correlated under this scenario, wider credit spreads will partially or fully offset the decline in government benchmark yields, resulting in lower empirical duration estimates than analytical duration estimates.

choices.itemBody: A. assumes that government bond yields and spreads are independent variables.
B. is higher than analytical duration for high-yield bonds under market stress scenarios.
C. uses statistical methods and historical bond prices to derive the price–yield relationship for bond portfolios.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06802
entry.itemBody:
An analyst observes the following information about a bond:

Yield to Maturity Full Price
1.35% 97.5
1.50% 97.0
1.65% 96.8

If the initial price of the bond is 97.0, the approximate convexity is closest to:

answerFeedback.25514972-de65-420c-a814-32c5254f1b61:
Correct because the approximate convexity statistic = ApproxCon = (PV− + PV+ − 2 × PV0) / [(ΔYield)2 × PV0] where:

PV− = price if yields decline

PV+ = price if yields rise

PV0 = initial price

ΔYield = change in yield in decimal form.

ApproxCon = [(97.5 + 96.8) − (2 × 97)] ÷ (0.00152 × 97) = 1,374.5704

ApproxCon = [194.3 − 194] ÷ (0.00000225 × 97) = 1,374.57, rounded to 1,375.
answerFeedback.372b3356-874a-4393-91c0-f1de08d14493:
Incorrect because when calculating the approximate convexity, the change in yield term in the denominator is doubled as in the approximate duration calculation.

ApproxCon ≠ (PV− + PV+ − 2 × PV0) / [2 × (ΔYield)2 × PV0] = (97.5 + 96.8 − 2 × 97) / (2 × 0.00152 × 97) = 687.29, rounded to 687.
answerFeedback.f5871a66-0944-4a55-999e-42f3552f4880:
Incorrect because the formula for the approximate duration is used instead of approximate convexity.

ApproxCon ≠ (PV− − PV+) / (2 × (ΔYield) × PV0) = (97.5 − 96.8) / (2 × 0.0015 × 97) = 2.405, rounded to 2.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Derivs-Lamba-04
entry.itemBody: Convenience yield provides a possible explanation as to why the current spot price of a commodity is:

answerFeedback.0bd52444-d47d-4cee-96ea-5567e6ea7aa5: Incorrect because, as described in the rationale for the correct answer, convenience yield provides a possible explanation as to why the spot price of a commodity is higher than (not equal to) the market’s expectation of its future price.
answerFeedback.810b3d6a-5a68-41db-9ce9-b721a93f063c: Incorrect because, as described in the rationale for the correct answer, convenience yield provides a possible explanation as to why the spot price of a commodity is higher (not lower) than the market’s expectation of its future price.
answerFeedback.9f962b6f-ed04-4fab-8819-d21108abf583: Correct because the spot price of the commodity could even be above the market’s expectation of its future price, a condition that would seem to imply a negative expected return. This scenario raises the question of why anyone would want to hold the commodity if its expected return is negative. The convenience yield provides a possible explanation that attributes an implied but non-financial expected return to the advantage of holding a commodity in short supply.

choices.itemBody: A. lower than the market’s expectation of the future spot price of the commodity.
B. equal to the market’s expectation of the future spot price of the commodity.
C. higher than the market’s expectation of the future spot price of the commodity.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607033
entry.itemBody: Given two otherwise identical bonds, when interest rates rise, the price of Bond A declines more than the price of Bond B. Compared with Bond B, Bond A most likely:

answerFeedback.01bb1eeb-a547-4387-9b9f-5109ff73b1ae: Incorrect because when interest rates rise, the price of a callable bond will not fall as much as an otherwise option-free bond.
answerFeedback.21f504fb-76cc-40b0-b42b-dbe539f12e01: Correct. The lower the coupon rate, the more sensitive the bond’s price is to changes in interest rates.
answerFeedback.ccec8e5c-8708-4a78-9968-b83fc8fba48d: Incorrect because the maturity would have to be longer for Bond A relative to Bond B.

entry.title: ITEM_20170601010
entry.itemBody: According to put–call–forward parity, the difference between the price of a put and the price of a call is most likely equal to the difference between:

answerFeedback.3e0f9567-8563-431c-8bdc-6ccb0b9c5ffc:
Correct because put-call-forward parity can be written as:

p0 – c0 = [X – F0(T)]/(1 + r)T

This means that the difference between the price of a put and the price of a call is equal to the difference between exercise price and forward price discounted at the risk-free rate.
answerFeedback.4fa28198-1c70-4183-85c6-be591304e040: Incorrect because neither put–call parity nor put–call–forward parity support this interpretation.
answerFeedback.9ef5f2bd-8867-4daf-96cd-b2d1a68601c5: Incorrect because neither put–call parity nor put–call–forward parity support this interpretation.

choices.itemBody: A. forward price and spot price discounted at the risk-free rate.
B. spot price and exercise price discounted at the risk-free rate.
C. exercise price and forward price discounted at the risk-free rate.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.01-Alt-Berlinicke-01
entry.itemBody: Cryptocurrencies can be issued by:

answerFeedback.a7055e82-35ed-459f-854b-49dc8b0efa66: Correct because while there were around 70 cryptocurrencies recorded in 2013, by early 2022, there were close to 10,000 different cryptocurrencies issued by corporations, organizations, and in many cases, individuals.
answerFeedback.c326b3d0-8f4b-4097-8f5b-38b6507c0262: Incorrect because cryptocurrencies are not only issued by corporations and organizations but also by individuals. While there were around 70 cryptocurrencies recorded in 2013, by early 2022, there were close to 10,000 different cryptocurrencies issued by corporations, organizations, and in many cases, individuals.
answerFeedback.fbf531ef-fd88-4fc7-9392-11771bbe006d: Incorrect because cryptocurrencies are not only issued by individuals but also by corporations and organizations. While there were around 70 cryptocurrencies recorded in 2013, by early 2022, there were close to 10,000 different cryptocurrencies issued by corporations, organizations, and in many cases, individuals.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Deriv-Lamba-03
entry.itemBody: Compared to exchange-traded derivatives, the relative transparency of over-the-counter derivatives is:

answerFeedback.3c2801b7-66fa-4e46-8a99-67a09f75eae0: Correct because over-the-counter derivatives are characterized by a lower degree of market transparency as many transactions in OTC markets will retain a degree of privacy with lower transparency. In contrast, exchange markets are said to have transparency, which means that full information on all transactions is disclosed to exchanges and regulatory bodies. So, over-the-counter derivatives have lower market transparency than exchange-traded derivatives.
answerFeedback.5ce9797c-6ccc-46f7-8980-f82c7db7bdce: Incorrect ​​​​​​because over-the-counter derivatives are characterized by a lower degree of market transparency as many transactions in OTC markets will retain a degree of privacy with lower transparency. In contrast, exchange markets are said to have transparency, which means that full information on all transactions is disclosed to exchanges and regulatory bodies. So, over-the-counter derivatives have lower market transparency than exchange-traded derivatives.
answerFeedback.927d8e74-6ba6-4c49-b089-4a599b52e78a: Incorrect because over-the-counter derivatives are characterized by a lower degree of market transparency as many transactions in OTC markets will retain a degree of privacy with lower transparency. In contrast, exchange markets are said to have transparency, which means that full information on all transactions is disclosed to exchanges and regulatory bodies. So, over-the-counter derivatives have lower market transparency than exchange-traded derivatives.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07922
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a bond:

Price if interest rates increase by 25 basis points 98
Price if interest rates decrease by 25 basis points 103

If the current price of the bond is 100, the annual modified duration is:

answerFeedback.631bf6c5-01b9-43f3-8d67-85b9bfd79d23:
Incorrect because it fails to multiply the change in yield by 2:

ApproxModDur ≠ (103 – 98) ÷ (0.0025 × 100) = 20.0.
answerFeedback.d217a891-7603-4cbd-ae96-5fe5f80a11c2:
Incorrect because it measures the numerator as a change from the current price:

ApproxModDur ≠ (103 – 100) ÷ (2 × 0.0025 × 100) = 6.0.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Equity-Bailey-01
entry.itemBody: Compared to the total return version of an index, the value of the price version of the index at inception is:

answerFeedback.0c7edd8b-58c0-4326-90c9-91761527858a: Correct because at inception, the values of the price and total return versions of an index are equal. As time passes, however, the value of the total return index will exceed the value of the price return index.
answerFeedback.1f20849e-e3bc-4669-b600-028481b86d0d: Incorrect because at inception, the values of the price and total return versions of an index are equal. As time passes, however, the value of the total return index will exceed the value of the price return index.
answerFeedback.55656bc2-c9bf-484b-a710-3c03295ec8ba: Incorrect because at inception, the values of the price and total return versions of an index are equal. As time passes, however, the value of the total return index will exceed the value of the price return index.

choices.itemBody: A. less than the value of the total return version.
B. equal to the value of the total return version.
C. greater than the value of the total return version.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-PM-Chua-05
entry.itemBody: With respect to derivatives, which of the following is a second-order risk?

answerFeedback.4bf4a12f-344b-4d3c-8467-720f8bb27ff1: Incorrect because vega is a first-order measure of the change in the derivative price for a change in the volatility of the underlying.
answerFeedback.b2fc5a53-09f4-486e-8e51-4794b1938fde: Correct because whereas delta is a first-order risk, gamma is considered a second-order risk because it reflects the risk of changes in delta.
answerFeedback.d15735c4-1bcf-4e91-8ea1-16fc9d274715: Incorrect because whereas delta is a first-order risk, gamma is considered a second-order risk because it reflects the risk of changes in delta.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-PM-Croitoru-02
entry.itemBody: Which of the following best describes the direct result of combining long-term capital market expectations with the objectives and constraints of a client's IPS?

answerFeedback.8293ca28-c08e-4b32-bdac-47d9ffc90135: Incorrect because the strategic asset allocation is the direct result of combining long-term capital market expectations with the IPS objectives and constraints. The strategic asset allocation decision is separate from the risk budgeting process. Risk budgeting is the process of deciding on the amount of risk to assume in a portfolio (the overall risk budget) and subdividing that risk over the sources of investment return (e.g., strategic asset allocation, tactical asset allocation, and security selection). Because the decision about the total amount of risk to be taken is made in constructing the IPS, at this stage we are concerned about the subdivision of that risk.
answerFeedback.bf560663-25cf-40df-bc2b-49116ebfdd79: Correct because a strategic asset allocation results from combining the constraints and objectives articulated in the IPS and long-term capital market expectations regarding the asset classes. The strategic asset allocation or policy portfolio will subsequently be implemented into real portfolios.
answerFeedback.cd20acef-696d-4d05-b2c5-7772419f9538: Incorrect because tactical asset allocation is the decision to deliberately deviate from the policy exposures to systematic risk factors (i.e., the policy weights of asset classes) with the intent to add value based on forecasts of the near-term returns of those asset classes. For instance, an investor may decide to temporarily invest more of the portfolio in equities than the SAA prescribes if the investor anticipates that equities will deliver a higher return over the short term than other asset classes. Combining long-term capital market expectations with the objectives and constraints of an IPS directly results in the strategic asset allocation, which precludes the tactical asset allocation decision.

choices.itemBody: A. The risk budget for the client's portfolio
B. The strategic asset allocation portfolio for the client
C. A tactical asset allocation decision for the client's portfolio

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07077
entry.itemBody: A stock is currently trading at €25.00 and the risk-free rate is 1.75% per annum. The minimum price of a 9-month European call option on the stock with an exercise price of €22.50 is closest to:

answerFeedback.3aeaa22a-f948-4e1a-9745-e04897f4ee7a: Incorrect because the minimum price for a European call option is not equal to the current stock price minus the exercise price or Max [0, S0 – X] = Max [€25.00 – €22.50] = Max [0, €2.50] = €2.50.
answerFeedback.90533442-1337-46fc-a669-bc4b91094032: Incorrect because the minimum price for a European call option is not equal to Max [0, S0 – X(1 + r)T] where the exercise price is multiplied instead of divided by (1 + r)T or Max [0, €25.00 – €22.50 × (1.0175)9/12] = Max [0, €25.00 – €22.79] = Max [0, €2.21] = €2.21.
answerFeedback.bdb7141d-3a6f-488b-9908-be974ee7e2c7: Correct because the minimum price for a European call option is calculated using the formula c0 ≥ Max [0, S0 – X / (1 + r)T] where c0 is the current price of the European call option, S0 is the current stock price, X is the strike price, r is the risk-free interest rate and T is time. Therefore the minimum price of a 9-month European call option is equal to or greater than Max [0, €25.00 – €22.50/(1.0175)9/12] = Max [0, €25.00 – €22.21] = Max [0, €2.79] = €2.79.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.08-Deriv-Tyler-01
entry.itemBody:
An analyst purchases the following derivatives with the same maturity date and underlying:

Type Price ($) Strike ($)
Forward 100 ---
Call option 3 100

If the profit on the call option is zero at maturity, the price of the forward at maturity is:

answerFeedback.be3b69ab-9a69-4652-9295-402e65cb140d: Incorrect because this does not consider the option premium. For the buyer of a call option with an exercise price of F0(T) (we have the following expression for the profit of the call option): Π = max[0, ST – F0(T)] – c0. If the profit on the call option is zero, then ST – F0(T) = $3 and F0(T) <> ST.
answerFeedback.d0b59eed-dd3a-4a42-a43c-fbd168dc7a16: Incorrect because for the buyer of a call option with an exercise price of F0(T) [we have the following expression for the profit of the call option]: Π = max[0, ST – F0(T)] – c0. If the profit on the call option is zero, then ST – F0(T) = $3 and F0(T) = ST – $3 (not ST + $3). The forward price is therefore less than, not greater than, the price of the underlying by the amount of the option premium.
answerFeedback.e4dc708b-6adb-47af-85dc-ff4e9d43c9d4: Correct because for the buyer of a call option with an exercise price of F0(T) (we have the following expression for the profit of the call option): Π = max[0, ST – F0(T)] – c0. If the profit on the call option is zero, then ST – F0(T) = $3 and F0(T) = ST – $3. The forward price is therefore less than the price of the underlying by the amount of the option premium.

choices.itemBody: A. less than the price of the underlying.
B. equal to the price of the underlying.
C. greater than the price of the underlying.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-PM-Leonida-04
entry.itemBody: Achieving a portfolio return that is within a band of plus or minus 2% of the portfolio's benchmark return with a 95% probability in any 12-month period is best described as a:

answerFeedback.862bdca3-f38a-4f4c-8341-f6b5c69facda: Incorrect because quantitative risk objectives can be absolute or relative or a combination of the two. Measures of absolute risk include the variance or standard deviation of returns and value at risk. Value at risk or VaR is a measure of the size of the tail of the distribution of profits on a portfolio or for an organization. On the other hand, the objective of a portfolio return being within a band of its benchmark is a relative risk objective.
answerFeedback.9fa2d9fb-a661-487e-b3a8-985e1c508022: Incorrect because a client’s return objectives can be stated in a number of ways. Similar to risk objectives, return objectives may be stated on an absolute or a relative basis. Alternatively, the return objective can be stated on a relative basis, for example, relative to a benchmark return. The benchmark could be an equity market index, such as the S&P 500 or the FTSE 100, or a cash rate of interest such as Libor. A relative return objective might be stated as, for example, a desire to outperform the benchmark index by one percentage point per year. On the other hand, the objective of a portfolio return being within a band of its benchmark in any time period with a given probability is a relative risk objective.
answerFeedback.c25e2855-e0ad-4105-8a89-dd6afc04c2d0: Correct because a relative risk objective may be expressed as a desire for the portfolio return to be within a band of plus or minus X percent of the benchmark return calculated by assigning an index or benchmark to represent each asset class present in the policy portfolio. This objective has to be interpreted as a statement of probability; for example, a 95 percent probability that the portfolio return will be within X percent of the benchmark return over a stated time period.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-PM-Tsependa-07
entry.itemBody: In efficient markets and over long periods of time, large company stocks are expected to have:

answerFeedback.0f8f50f5-ddc4-487c-bdd8-9523083b7acf: Incorrect because large company stocks typically have lower risk and lower return in efficient markets over long time periods. A higher return is not possible to attain in efficient markets and over long periods of time without accepting higher risk. Expected returns should be greater for assets with greater risk.
answerFeedback.34e25604-5344-40ef-8a31-20d3299c6a58: Incorrect because large company stocks typically have lower risk and lower return in efficient markets over long time periods. A higher return is not possible to attain in efficient markets and over long periods of time without accepting higher risk. Expected returns should be greater for assets with greater risk.
answerFeedback.452150f2-49bd-445b-bf95-c138f843af72: Correct because a higher return is not possible to attain in efficient markets and over long periods of time without accepting higher risk. Expected returns should be greater for assets with greater risk. Also, based on empirical evidence for the United States, small company stocks had higher risk and higher return than large company stocks.

choices.itemBody: A. lower returns and lower risk than small company stocks.
B. higher returns and lower risk than small company stocks.
C. higher returns and higher risk than small company stocks.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kassem-24
entry.itemBody: If a bond has a modified duration of 6.2 and convexity of 42.8, the percentage change in price for a 50 basis point increase in yield is closest to:

answerFeedback.2e60005d-a48a-4c4d-b7d9-bf5632186d0f: Incorrect because the %ΔPVFull ≈ (–AnnModDur × ΔYield) + (1/2 x AnnConvexity × (ΔYield)2). This incorrect answer subtracts the convexity portion of the equation rather than adding. Using the data provided, (–6.2 × 0.005) – (1/2 × 42.8 × (0.005)2 = –0.031 – 0.00054 = –0.03154  ≈ –0.0315  or –3.15%.
answerFeedback.47793815-9fad-4429-8023-84632068f22d: Correct because the %ΔPVFull ≈ (-AnnModDur × ΔYield) + (1/2 x AnnConvexity × (ΔYield)2). Using the data provided, (– 6.2 × 0.005) + (1/2 × 42.8 × (0.005)2 = –0.031 + 0.00054 =  –0.03047 ≈ –0.0305  or –3.05%.
answerFeedback.4b1cc37a-d319-4c45-a6b0-9d53b6397120: Incorrect because the %ΔPVFull ≈ (-AnnModDur × ΔYield) + (1/2 x AnnConvexity × (ΔYield)2). This incorrect answer multiplies the wrong side of the equation by 1/2 to be (–6.2 × 0.005 × 1/2) +  42.8 × (0.005)2 = –0.01550 + 0.00107 = –0.01443 or –1.44%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09865
entry.itemBody: An annual-pay option-free bond has a 3.5% coupon and three years until maturity. If the current price of this bond is 90, the market discount rate is closest to:

answerFeedback.8b86b554-5688-46af-ba09-0e9cf80216f8:
Correct because the general formula for calculating a bond price given the market discount rate is:

PV = [PMT ÷ (1 + r)1] + [PMT ÷ (1 + r)2] +…+ [(PMT + FV) ÷ (1 + r)N]

Where:

PV = present value, or the price of the bond

PMT = coupon payment per period

FV = future value paid at maturity, or the par value of the bond

r = market discount rate, or required rate of return per period

N = number of evenly spaced periods to maturity.

Or, using calculator inputs, PMT = 3.50 or (3.5% × 100); FV = 100; N = 3; PV = –90.00 (90% × –100,00). Solve for I = 7.33378% ≈ 7.33%.
answerFeedback.b0cd71e1-4fd7-4540-8793-ace589307e6a: Incorrect because it interchanges the years to maturity (3) as the coupon rate, and the coupon rate (3.50) as the number of years until maturity. Using calculator inputs, PMT = 3.00 or (3.0% × 100); FV = 100; N = 3.5; PV = –90.00. Solve for I = 6.2704 ≈ 6.27%.
answerFeedback.c1cc4987-d0a4-4b52-90d4-53e5a0a099de: Incorrect because it calculates the discount rate based on a semi-annual pay bond instead of the annual pay bond given. Using calculator inputs, PMT = 1.75 or (3.5% ÷ 2 × 100); FV = 100; N = 6 (or 3 × 2); PV = –90.00. Solve for I ≠ 3.63501% semi-annually, or 7.2700266% annually ≈ 7.27%.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B PM 04MXC
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a security and the market for a 12-month period:

  Realized Return Beta
Security 10.5% 0.8
Market 12.0% 1.0

The risk-free rate is 2.0%. According to the market model, the security’s abnormal return for the period is closest to:

answerFeedback.09d1f5ff-10d4-4626-833f-a782ac004c63: Incorrect because the market model is incorrectly stated as Ri = Rf + βiRm + ei, which results in ei = 0.105 – 0.02 – 0.8 × 0.12 = –0.011 = –1.1%. This is also closest to the calculation 0.8 × (0.105 – 0.12) = –0.012 = –1.2%.
answerFeedback.8420549d-d767-401f-b7b9-36f7d927d1a0: Correct because the abnormal return of a security during a period is the difference between expected return and realized return, or the error term ei in the market model, Ri = αi + βiRm + ei. The term αi is Rf × (1 – βi) = 0.02 × 0.2 = 0.004, which results in ei = 0.105 – 0.004 – 0.8 × 0.12 = 0.005 = 0.5%. Another approach to compute the abnormal return of a security is using the capital asset pricing model, E(Ri) = Rf + βi(Rm – Rf), such that E(Ri) = 0.02 + 0.8 × (0.12 – 0.02) = 0.10. It follows that the abnormal return of the security is 0.105 – 0.10 = 0.005 = 0.5%.
answerFeedback.f747bf3f-7d02-46d1-8b49-d733c82fff55: Incorrect because the abnormal return of a security during a period is the difference between expected return and realized return, or the error term ei in the market model, Ri = αi + βiRm + ei. However, the term αi is incorrectly computed as Rf × (–βi) = 0.02 × (–0.8) = –0.016, which results in ei = 0.105 + 0.016 – 0.8 × 0.12 = 0.025 = 2.5%. This is equivalent to omitting the risk-free rate as the first term in the CAPM approach of solving the question, such that E(Ri) = 0.8 × (0.12 – 0.02) = 0.08. It follows that the abnormal return of the security is incorrectly computed as 0.105 – 0.08 = 0.025 = 2.5%.

entry.title: ITEM_20170427042
entry.itemBody:
A hedge fund with an initial value of $100 million has a management fee of 2% and an incentive fee of 20%. Management and incentive fees are calculated independently using end-of-period valuation. The value must reach the previous high-water mark before incentive fees are paid. The table below provides end-of-period fund values (in $ millions) for the last three years.

Year Before Fees After Fees
1 120 113.6
2 110 107.8
3 125 ---

The total amount of fees earned by the hedge fund in Year 3 is closest to:

answerFeedback.0deda59b-1b1f-44db-b4cf-b91f49120c75:
Incorrect because the incentive fee is incorrectly based on the fund value after fees in the second year.

Management fee: 2% of $125 million = $2.5 million

Incentive fee: 20% of ($125 million – $107.8 million) = $3.44 million

In total: $2.5 million + $3.44 million = $5.94 million
answerFeedback.77be492d-3c88-4296-9b02-ce4997351f9a:
Incorrect because the incentive fee is incorrectly based on the fund value before fees in the second year.

Management fee: 2% of $125 million = $2.5 million

Incentive fee: 20% of ($125 million – $110 million) = $3 million

In total: $2.5 million + $3 million = $5.5 million
answerFeedback.ac008473-d722-4a1a-ac53-a43c5e0b8a60:
Correct because the incentive fee is based on the performance relative to the previous high-water mark after fees.

Management fee: 2% of $125 million = $2.5 million

Incentive fee: 20% of ($125 million – $113.6 million) = $2.28 million

In total: $2.5 million + $2.28 million = $4.78 million

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-Alt-Tsependa-12
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements about real estate assets is most accurate?

answerFeedback.544d2d2b-d4bc-4d2f-9f5b-5ef4ce0bc457: Incorrect because real estate property has some unique features, including heterogeneity (not homogeneity) (no two properties are identical) and fixed location.
answerFeedback.63d0d887-8eb3-4df8-a134-d0feb305a08b: Incorrect because real estate includes two major sectors: residential and commercial. Residential [not commercial] real estate is the largest sector, totaling 75% of the global market.
answerFeedback.dd689193-90fe-4de8-98e6-ce4da52817b2: Correct because the key reasons for investing in (private) real estate include potential benefits like historically low correlations with other asset classes.

choices.itemBody: B. Commercial property represents the majority of real estate assets by value
C. Private real estate has historically had low correlations with other asset classes

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09871
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is an assumption of the CAPM?

answerFeedback.50a1ee86-7ab3-4534-bf56-1dd2f579eb87: Incorrect because the CAPM assumes that investors plan for the same single holding period. The CAPM is a single-period model, and all investor decisions are made on the basis of that one period.
answerFeedback.b6aa43a5-1bb8-4044-9320-ce6608645787: Incorrect because an assumption of the CAPM is that investors are price takers. The CAPM assumes that there are many investors and that no investor is large enough to influence prices. Thus, investors are price takers, and we assume that security prices are unaffected by investor trades.
answerFeedback.f6b141e7-4e07-4d27-be91-8c75ec514b97: Correct because the CAPM assumes that markets are frictionless, including no transaction costs and no taxes.

choices.itemBody: B. Investors plan for multiple holding periods.
C. Large investors can influence security prices.

entry.title: ITEM_20190530038
entry.itemBody: The price of a pay-fixed receive-floating interest rate swap is most likely:

answerFeedback.289a0393-13a5-47aa-8de2-308d44cdb356: Correct because the price of the swap is the fixed rate on the swap at the start of the transaction such that the present value of fixed payments is equal to the present value of the floating payments and the market value of the swap is zero.
answerFeedback.6beb13db-33ce-4011-9361-0f00bf822534: Incorrect because these calculations provide the market value of the swap to one of the parties.
answerFeedback.e67ae000-55f6-4005-837b-b526bef753b3: Incorrect because these calculations provide the market value of the swap to one of the parties.

choices.itemBody: A. the fixed rate that results when the market value of the swap is zero at initiation.
B. the sum of the fixed-rate payments minus the sum of the floating-rate payments.
C. the present value of the floating-rate payments minus the present value of the fixed-rate payments.

entry.title: ITEM_20180516060
entry.itemBody: The effective convexity of a bond is a measurement of the effect of a change in:

answerFeedback.6368d278-8b16-4c4c-88c0-09f8e283bf85: Incorrect because effective convexity measures the effect of a change in a benchmark yield curve, not the effect of a change in the horizon yield.
answerFeedback.b56b817e-8c2d-492b-a8c5-79b98ca9d1c7: Correct because the effective convexity of a bond is a curve convexity statistic that measures the secondary effect of a change in a benchmark yield curve.
answerFeedback.bbbb4aad-25f6-4043-8371-d8fb8038c1a6: Incorrect because approximate convexity measures the effect of a change in the yield to maturity, whereas effective convexity measures the effect of a change in a benchmark yield curve.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09872
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about two assets:

Asset Expected Return Standard Deviation of Returns
1 –5% 5%
2 5% 8%

If the correlation between the two assets' returns is –1, the standard deviation of returns for an equally weighted portfolio of the assets is closest to:

answerFeedback.42bcd4a7-ae90-45b0-8892-0f0086b2f259: Incorrect because it omits the 2 in the correct formula; w12σ12 + w22σ22 + w1w2ρ12σ1σ2 = (0.52 × 0.052) + (0.52 × 0.092) + (0.5 × 0.5 × –1 × 0.05 × 0.09) = 0.001525, which gives a portfolio standard deviation of √0.001525 = 0.03905 = 3.9% ≈ 4%. It is also the variance if 0.0004 was interpreted as 4%. Alternatively, it is the difference between the standard deviations of both assets; 9% – 5% = 4%.
answerFeedback.6e0f2dd3-4b21-4d0c-8cc8-0b41fcb38dae: Correct because the portfolio variance can be calculated using the formula: σp2 = w12σ12 + w22σ22 + 2w1w2ρ12σ1σ2, where wi denotes the portfolio weights, σi the asset standard deviations, and ρ12 the correlation between the returns on the two assets; σp2 = (0.52 × 0.052) + (0.52 × 0.092) + (2 × 0.5 × 0.5 × –1 × 0.05 × 0.09) = 0.0004. The standard deviation is σp = √0.0004 = 0.02 = 2%. In fact, when two assets are perfectly negatively correlated, the portfolio standard deviation is σp = |w1σ1 – w2σ2| = |0.5 × 0.05 – 0.5 × 0.09| = |–0.02| = 2%.
answerFeedback.a64fe462-2169-4bfc-a299-8e42f85a24ec: Incorrect because for the case in which ρ12 = –1 (that is, the two asset returns move in opposite directions), the portfolio can be made risk free. However, in this particular example the portfolio weights are not sufficient to make the portfolio risk free. This answer is also closest to the intermediate step of calculating the variance; σp2 = (0.52 × 0.052) + (0.52 × 0.092) + (2 × 0.5 × 0.5 × –1 × 0.05 × 0.09) = 0.0004, which could be interpreted as 0.04% ≈ 0%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-Alt-Loo-15
entry.itemBody: Which of the following offers the flexibility of delaying harvests when their prices are down?

answerFeedback.1a513a5f-3f60-4b6e-926d-54d08d718be9: Correct because timberland serves as both a factory and a warehouse. Timber (trees) can be grown (i.e., timberland’s factory characteristic) and easily stored by simply not harvesting the trees (i.e., timberland’s warehouse characteristic). This characteristic offers the flexibility of harvesting when timber prices are up and delaying harvests when prices are down.
answerFeedback.640e624c-07f2-464d-ba94-13f0a433fb20: Incorrect because farm products must be harvested when ripe, with little flexibility in production. By contrast, timberland serves as both a factory and a warehouse. Timber (trees) can be grown (i.e., timberland’s factory characteristic) and easily stored by simply not harvesting the trees (i.e., timberland’s warehouse characteristic). This characteristic offers the flexibility of harvesting when timber prices are up and delaying harvests when prices are down.
answerFeedback.645e0c48-2569-4214-ac75-611c7538ee6c: Incorrect because farm products must be harvested when ripe, with little flexibility in production. By contrast, timberland serves as both a factory and a warehouse. Timber (trees) can be grown (i.e., timberland’s factory characteristic) and easily stored by simply not harvesting the trees (i.e., timberland’s warehouse characteristic). This characteristic offers the flexibility of harvesting when timber prices are up and delaying harvests when prices are down.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-PM-Tsependa-01
entry.itemBody: A multi-boutique asset manager firm is best described as a(n):

answerFeedback.1016a11b-a26e-4072-9e0b-212e247d3335: Correct because multi-boutique is a type of asset manager firm in which a holding company owns several asset management firms that typically have specialized investment strategies.
answerFeedback.c08231ce-248d-4fa2-a714-a95f59544a20: Incorrect because these are full-service (not multi-boutique) asset management companies that offer a wide variety of asset classes and style. Another type of asset manager firm is a 'multi-boutique,' in which a holding company owns several asset management firms that typically have specialized investment strategies.
answerFeedback.d027f20e-51d8-4422-bf16-5170bc97a482: Incorrect because these are specialist (not multi-boutique) asset management companies that focus on a specific asset class (e.g., emerging market equities) or style (e.g., quantitative investing). Another type of asset manager firm is a 'multi-boutique,' in which a holding company owns several asset management firms that typically have specialized investment strategies.

choices.itemBody: A. asset management company that focuses on a specific asset class or style.
B. asset management company that offers a wide variety of asset classes and styles.
C. holding company which owns several asset management firms with specialized investment strategies.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Islam-10
entry.itemBody: Industry classification systems are developed by:

answerFeedback.16752459-1357-442c-b5c8-06f78b43ae57: Incorrect because classification systems are developed and used by both commercial entities and various governmental agencies.
answerFeedback.415ffb25-8327-4e8e-9592-e8716eb519d4: Incorrect because classification systems are developed and used by both commercial entities and various governmental agencies.
answerFeedback.9b12be2f-00c3-487b-bacc-e246a3da541f: Correct because classification systems are developed and used by both commercial entities and various governmental agencies.

choices.itemBody: C. both commercial entities and government agencies.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-PM-Chua-01
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements about endowments and foundations is most accurate?

answerFeedback.474d4bbc-1db4-4f15-98a3-25543e1443d1: Correct because endowments and foundations typically allocate a sizable portion of their assets in alternative investments.
answerFeedback.94f6d2f2-d4d8-46ac-ad93-e2edffde54dc: Incorrect because foundations are grant-making entities, while endowments are funds of non-profit institutions that help the institutions provide designated services.
answerFeedback.e4f4109f-d734-4a91-848c-19668c83d6d6: Incorrect because most foundations and endowments are established with the intent of having perpetual lives.

choices.itemBody: A. Most endowments and foundations have relatively short time horizons.
B. Endowments typically allocate a sizable portion of their assets in alternative investments.
C. Foundations are funds of non-profit institutions that help the institutions provide designated services.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606039
entry.itemBody: Last year, a portfolio manager earned a return of 12%. The portfolio’s beta was 1.5. For the same period, the market return was 7.5%, and the average risk-free rate was 2.7%. Jensen’s alpha for this portfolio is closest to:

answerFeedback.3f86b702-2469-4883-9e0b-c5c3668c6676: Incorrect because the calculation omits the risk-free rate from the calculation: 0.12 – 1.5(0.075) = 0.0075 or 0.75%.
answerFeedback.6419732e-3f20-466e-940c-6ba95422d49c: Incorrect because this result is simply the portfolio return minus the market return = 0.12 – 0.75 = 0.045 or 4.5%.
answerFeedback.b1844150-1e2a-4742-8e4b-cecd64d37fb9: Correct because Jensen’s alpha = portfolio return – [average risk-free rate + portfolio beta (market return – risk-free rate)] = 0.12 – [0.027 + 1.5(0.075 – 0.027)] = 0.021 or 2.10%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01877
entry.itemBody: An investor purchases stock at $25 per share on 55% initial margin. If the required maintenance margin is 25%, a margin call may first occur when the price falls below:

answerFeedback.7ec56ffa-4bea-43b5-b354-c7e5f590e3d4: Incorrect because the margin percentage and borrowing percentage are interchanged: 0.45 × $25 = $11.25. (equity / share) / (price / share) = 25% = $11.25 + (P − $25) / P = 25%; P = $18.33.
answerFeedback.d7d9fd85-a29e-4013-8bb5-8b041c1ef3a5: Correct because the investor's initial equity is 55% of the initial stock price, or 0.55 × $25 = $13.75. Equity per share = $13.75 + (P − $25) where P is the current share price. The price below which a margin call will take place is equal to the maintenance margin: (equity / share) / (price / share) = 25% = [$13.75 + (P − $25)] / P; Solving for P: 0.75P = 11.25; P = $15.00.
answerFeedback.de15e15a-8d47-41d0-9b20-d800833a94a2: Incorrect because it is the purchase price multiplied by the initial margin requirement = $25 × 0.55 = $13.75.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516070
entry.itemBody: The MSCI All Country World Index is best described as a:

answerFeedback.1adfc45d-1878-4cc4-9789-35b3b0e7c474: Correct because the MSCI All Country World Index is a multi-market equity index because it represents stocks of 23 developed and 24 emerging markets.
answerFeedback.b4b34d0c-101e-4140-b667-55fcc9aed5bb: Incorrect because the MSCI All Country World Index represents stocks of 23 developed and 24 emerging markets, whereas a broad market index includes securities of only a single selected market.
answerFeedback.c431d658-1444-44b1-b458-433733c4934e: Incorrect because the MSCI All Country World Index is composed of global stocks, but it doesn’t represent specific economic sectors.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03725
entry.itemBody: An equal-weighted index most likely:

answerFeedback.b01e8ade-2d4b-4a0b-a35e-e4ac44a8c718: Incorrect because after the index is constructed and the prices of constituent securities change, the index is no longer equally weighted. Therefore, maintaining equal weights requires frequent adjustments (rebalancing) to the index.
answerFeedback.f35418df-4207-4a9b-b97c-f25a54cf11d9: Correct because securities that constitute the largest fraction of the target market value are underrepresented, and securities that constitute a small fraction of the target market value are overrepresented.
answerFeedback.fa6ab399-fdba-4ef8-b05c-dc4d8951c3e3: Incorrect because an equally-weighted index weights each security equally regardless of market price.

choices.itemBody: B. has weights arbitrarily assigned by market prices.
C. underrepresents large cap securities versus the target market.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-PM-Huffman-04
entry.itemBody: Which of the following best describes an appropriate use of a client's IPS by an investment manager?

answerFeedback.676cbd3a-de97-41c5-bd47-e6d37865d370: Correct because an investment manager should build the portfolio with reference to the IPS and be able to refer to it to assess the suitability of a particular investment for the client.
answerFeedback.c6f8a9d2-3d21-4a66-af52-4e76a27fa984: Incorrect because an IPS can take a variety of forms. A typical format will include the client's investment objectives and the constraints that apply to the client’s portfolio. The client's objectives are specified in terms of risk tolerance and return requirements. These must be consistent with each other: a client is unlikely to be able to find a portfolio that offers a relatively high expected return without taking on a relatively high level of expected risk. Therefore, the manager should include both the risk objective and return objective when using the IPS to make investment decisions.
answerFeedback.ea6cec30-b85f-4a57-9c35-14445a42bc84: Incorrect because an IPS can take a variety of forms. A typical format will include the client's investment objectives and the constraints that apply to the client’s portfolio. The client's objectives are specified in terms of risk tolerance and return requirements. These must be consistent with each other: a client is unlikely to be able to find a portfolio that offers a relatively high expected return without taking on a relatively high level of expected risk. Therefore, the manager should include both the risk objective and return objective when using the IPS to make investment decisions.

choices.itemBody: A. Assessing the suitability of a particular investment for the client
B. Selecting investments that maximize a client's return irrespective of risk
C. Allocating funds in a way that minimizes risk exposure irrespective of the client's return objective

entry.title: ITEM_20170516124
entry.itemBody:
An investor gathers the following information about a company:

Current dividend per share $3
Historical annual dividend growth rate 4%
Expected annual dividend growth rate for the next three years 8%
Expected stock value per share at the end of Year 3 $33

If the investors’ required rate of return is 15%, the current estimate of the intrinsic value per share is closest to:

answerFeedback.744e3aef-b64a-4e02-92bd-1cab83af0c1f:
Correct because the value equals the present value of future cash flows over the next three years, plus the expected stock price in three years (discounted back to present value). Numerically, this looks like:

V0 = $3 × (1+0.08)/(1+0.15) + $3 × (1+0.08)2/(1+0.15)2 + $3 × (1+0.08)3/(1+0.15)3 + $33/(1+0.15)3 

= 2.82 + 2.65 + 2.48 + 21.70

= $29.65
answerFeedback.937498a3-5dd2-4db6-9bef-1fcacb4c144b:
Incorrect. It uses the historical growth rate rather than an analyst’s growth forecast, which looks like:

V0 = $3 × (1+0.04)/(1+0.15) + $3 × (1+0.04)2/(1+0.15)2 + $3 × (1+0.04)3/(1+0.15)3 + $33/(1+0.15)3 

= 2.71 + 2.45 + 2.22 + 21.70

= $29.08
answerFeedback.cf6c62ff-5ef0-4f1c-aede-911771a11151:
Incorrect. It uses the historical growth rate and the constant growth model for estimating the intrinsic value, which looks like:

V0 = D0 × (1 + g)/(r-g).  

Plugging in values:

V0 = 3× (1 + 0.04)/(0.15-0.04).  

V0 = $28.36

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-Alt-Tsependa-20
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most likely a high-risk infrastructure investment?

answerFeedback.51712e45-53a2-4f7c-b7b4-d4947270288f: Incorrect because an investment in a brownfield asset leased back to a government represents a low-risk infrastructure investment, as does an investment in assets with a history of steady cash flows, such as certain established toll roads.
answerFeedback.c6aaae4a-3885-432e-b09f-86142969d6bf: Correct because greenfield projects without guarantees of demand upon completion—e.g., variable electricity prices, uncertain traffic on roads and through ports, are examples of higher-risk profile investments.
answerFeedback.fa3dd843-40de-470e-9d5a-dce968321b88: Incorrect because an investment in a brownfield asset leased back to a government represents a low-risk infrastructure investment, as does an investment in assets with a history of steady cash flows, such as certain established toll roads.

choices.itemBody: A. An asset with a history of steady cash flows
B. A brownfield asset leased back to a government
C. A greenfield project without guarantees of demand upon completion

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-Alt-Augulyte-15
entry.itemBody: Mezzanine debt most likely:

answerFeedback.16a65097-8a62-43d2-a437-b10703121883: Correct because mezzanine debt often comes with additional features, such as warrants or conversion rights.
answerFeedback.1c1ebfcb-4f07-4df1-8430-86e8adec2ccb: Incorrect because mezzanine debt refers to private credit subordinated to senior secured debt but senior to equity in the borrower’s capital structure.
answerFeedback.def8a5bf-26ad-4738-af85-0e954f727270: Incorrect because mezzanine debt typically has a junior ranking and unsecured status.

choices.itemBody: C. is subordinated to equity in the borrower's capital structure.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Derivs-Lin-01
entry.itemBody: An investor buys a call option for $5 with an exercise price of $100 when the underlying price is $99. The value to the call option buyer if the price of the underlying is $108 at expiration is:

answerFeedback.32817943-2ce9-4231-bf88-ba44b70cede4: Correct because the call buyer's value at expiration = cT = Max (0, ST – X), where ST = Spot price at expiration and X = exercise price. Therefore, call buyer's value at expiration = Max(0, $108 – $100) = $8.
answerFeedback.ddcc6cd3-99b5-4df0-8237-e3883df7ef4b: Incorrect because it wrongly calculates the call buyer's value at expiration as Max(0, ST – S0) – c0, where ST = Spot price at expiration, S0 = Spot price at initiation and c0 is the call value at initiation, which is Max(0, $108 – $99) – $5 = $4.
answerFeedback.e051e683-7b36-4f63-9acb-2fb2b7bee901: Incorrect because it calculates call buyer's profit at expiration = Π = cT – c0 where cT is the call value at expiration and c0 is the call value at initiation. Therefore, Π = cT – c0 = Max(0, $108 – $100) – $5 = $3.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10708
entry.itemBody: For an equally weighted portfolio, an increase in the correlations between asset returns most likely decreases the:

answerFeedback.176fe335-0a97-48e4-a5a3-88285e5a91f2:
Correct because, as the correlations between asset returns increase, the diversification benefit provided by portfolios decreases. A major reason that portfolios can effectively reduce risk is that combining securities whose returns do not move together provides diversification. However, an important issue is that the co-movement or correlation pattern of the securities' returns in the portfolio can change in a manner unfavorable to the investor. When we examine the returns of a set of global equity indexes over the last 15 years, we observe a reduction in the diversification benefit due to a change in the pattern of co-movements of returns. The degree to which these global equity indexes move together has increased over time.

The lesson is that although portfolio diversification generally does reduce risk, it does not necessarily provide the same level of risk reduction during times of severe market turmoil as it does when the economy and markets are operating ‘normally'.
answerFeedback.30e07b76-6231-421f-86eb-2e04e14ca556:
Incorrect because the standard deviation of an equally weighted portfolio is not simply the average of the standard deviations of the individual shares. Such a portfolio offers a lower standard deviation of return than the average of its individual components due to the correlations or interactions between the individual securities. Thus, a portfolio's standard deviation of returns is influenced by the correlations between assets.

For example, the standard deviation of a two-asset portfolio simplifies to the following:

σp = √(w12σ12 + w22σ22 + 2w1w2ρ12σ1σ2). It follows that an increase in the correlation among assets will result in an increase in the portfolio's standard deviation, not a decrease.
answerFeedback.94e4a1f2-0575-4b3c-9c04-dd00a22dfe8b: Incorrect because the equally weighted portfolio's return is the same as the return on the randomly selected security. Thus, a portfolio's expected return is not influenced by the correlations between assets. The portfolio return varies with weights but is unaffected by the correlation coefficient.

choices.itemBody: C. level of risk reduction provided by the portfolio.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03828
entry.itemBody: Short sellers most likely:

answerFeedback.0ad7844b-60fc-4a72-afd1-ce01606e86cf: Incorrect because if you sell a stock you own, you no longer have a position in that stock. Therefore only a borrowed stock can be short sold. Short sellers create short positions in contracts by selling contracts that they do not own.
answerFeedback.c138eaf7-afa2-4e7a-af6c-911dcd8c5539: Incorrect because the potential gains on a short position are limited to no more than 100 percent whereas the potential losses are unbounded. The unbounded potential losses on short positions make short positions very risky in volatile instruments.
answerFeedback.fbf43e50-9dec-43d2-ac8b-8fc32c4d9c4f: Correct because short sellers create short positions in securities by borrowing securities from security lenders who are long holders. The short sellers then sell the borrowed securities to other traders.

choices.itemBody: C. cannot lose more than their initial investment.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-Deriv-Bangaruswamy-03
entry.itemBody: The time value of an option is equal to the:

answerFeedback.27d636a9-b7f9-49a9-8c93-803def3e51fd: Incorrect because the time value of an option is the difference between the market price of the option and its intrinsic value.
answerFeedback.5fd31a90-4dfc-4db5-a4a5-f0634db17a10: Incorrect because the time value of an option is the difference between the market price of the option and its intrinsic value.
answerFeedback.8c76adaa-2b46-42bb-9781-e24464baa7df: Correct because the time value of an option is the difference between the market price of the option and its intrinsic value.

choices.itemBody: A. option price minus the intrinsic value of the option.
B. strike price of the option minus the underlying price.
C. strike price of the option minus the intrinsic value of the option.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516110
entry.itemBody: In the semi-strong-form of market efficiency, fundamental analysis most likely requires the analyst to:

answerFeedback.11036777-4f8e-4475-8b79-6da0a562fc28: Incorrect because simply extrapolating historical data may not produce superior returns in an efficient market.
answerFeedback.311d0951-1e71-401b-bbd5-9facceb3ec89: Correct because fundamental analysis facilitates a semi-strong-form efficient market by disseminating value-relevant information. Fundamental analysis can be profitable in terms of generating abnormal returns if the analyst creates a comparative advantage with respect to this information. Such an advantage can be achieved by doing a superior job of estimating the relevant variables and predicting earnings surprises.
answerFeedback.6f96ff3d-65ab-4668-9466-c468e6631fd5: Incorrect because the use of technical rules for detecting the price movements and gradual price adjustments comprises technical analysis, not fundamental analysis.

choices.itemBody: A. extrapolate historical data to estimate future values and make investment decisions.
B. use trading rules for detecting the price movements that lead to new equilibrium prices.
C. do a superior job of estimating the relevant variables and predicting earnings surprises.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607097
entry.itemBody: Which one of the following is least likely to be an example of a Eurobond?

answerFeedback.499752f4-4e97-48c7-a0ca-4f86bfc4ef84: Correct because it is an example of a foreign bond, that is, a bond issued by a foreign company in the domestic market of the country in whose currency the bond is denominated.
answerFeedback.599d97c1-dece-48f9-a69d-a83ba08c9435: Incorrect because this is an example of a Eurodollar bond.
answerFeedback.95f19b66-7b1b-4c7f-9d10-aa6b0885752c: Incorrect because this is an example of a euro-denominated Eurobond.

choices.itemBody: A. An Australian company issuing US$-denominated bonds to investors domiciled in Japan
B. A UK-based company issuing Japanese yen-denominated bonds to investors domiciled in Japan
C. A Japanese company issuing euro-denominated bonds to investors domiciled in the United Kingdom

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03287
entry.itemBody: Securities dealers most likely:

answerFeedback.593a8469-14db-4038-8ca0-170a31afb691: Incorrect because arranging an IPO is a role of an investment bank, not a dealer. Investment banks provide advice to their mostly corporate clients and help them arrange transactions such as initial and seasoned securities offerings.
answerFeedback.5e52e1e8-8f6c-4046-be3a-778097de1b79: Correct because the service that dealers provide is liquidity. Dealers are proprietary traders who buy and sell securities from and to their clients, thereby providing liquidity.
answerFeedback.bcf55b93-8f1f-4e7b-b95b-c78a5e162250: Incorrect because securitizers, not dealers, securitize assets. Banks and investment companies create new financial products when they buy and repackage securities or other assets. The process of buying assets, placing them in a pool, and then selling securities that represent ownership of the pool is called securitization.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Derivs-Lee-06
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most accurate? Market participants most likely derive implied volatility from:

answerFeedback.7f0ade1e-42e4-461b-84d6-09abae8d9d9a: Correct because option prices reflect several characteristics of the underlying, including the expected price risk of the underlying, known as implied volatility. The implied volatility of an option may be derived from its current price and other option features and provides a measure of the general level of uncertainty in the price of the underlying.
answerFeedback.95793434-9dcc-4271-b918-082dde049291: Incorrect because, not futures, but option prices reflect several characteristics of the underlying, including the expected price risk of the underlying, known as implied volatility. The implied volatility of an option may be derived from its current price and other option features and provides a measure of the general level of uncertainty in the price of the underlying.
