answerFeedback.ac306f7c-3731-4a62-8d74-9f0312077747: Incorrect because, not swaps, but option prices reflect several characteristics of the underlying, including the expected price risk of the underlying, known as implied volatility. The implied volatility of an option may be derived from its current price and other option features and provides a measure of the general level of uncertainty in the price of the underlying.

choices.itemBody: A. swaps.
B. futures.
C. options.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kassem-04
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about spot rates:

Years to Maturity Spot Rate
1 1%
2 3%
3 4%

Given this information, the price of a three-year bond with a 4% coupon is closest to:

answerFeedback.238360a1-700f-4f86-903c-d0064409b220:
Incorrect because the formula for calculating a bond price given the sequence of spot rates: 

PV= PMT/(1+Z1)1 + PMT/(1+Z2)2 + (PMT-+FV)/(1+ZN)N where Z1 = spot rate for Period 1, Z2 = spot rate for Period 2, ZN = spot rate for Period N This solution fails to square and cube the denominator. Price = 4/(1.01)1 + 4/(1.03) + 104/(1.04) = 3.96 + 3.88 + 100 ≈ 107.84 ≈ 107.8.
answerFeedback.39d2f819-3628-4265-ab27-f8a98168108e:
Correct because the formula for calculating a bond price given the sequence of spot rates:

PV= PMT/(1+Z1)1 + PMT/(1+Z2)2 + (PMT+FV)/(1+ZN)N where Z1 = spot rate for Period 1, Z2 = spot rate for Period 2, ZN = spot rate for Period N Price = 4/(1.01)1 + 4/(1.03)2 + 104/(1.04)3 = 3.96 + 3.77 + 92.46 ≈ 100.19
answerFeedback.e3d5aec4-d0b2-4a15-a1b1-b05d44cb6cab:
Incorrect because the formula for calculating a bond price given the sequence of spot rates: 

PV= PMT/(1+Z1)1 + PMT/(1+Z2)2 + (PMT-+FV)/(1+ZN)N where Z1 = spot rate for Period 1, Z2 = spot rate for Period 2, ZN = spot rate for Period N This solution uses the sum of all payments as the numerator and the average spot rate in the denominator. Price = 112/(1.0267)3= 103.49 ≈ 103.5.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-Alt-Kashyap-08
entry.itemBody: Two private equity funds doubled the value of their investments. All else being equal, if Fund 1 achieved this return in less time than Fund 2, the multiple of invested capital (MOIC) of Fund 1 is:

answerFeedback.84fecbec-65c9-4e41-8c06-6bc4e0abe435: Incorrect because the MOIC ignores the timing of cash flows.
answerFeedback.ae3bb692-9975-471c-8928-9740a2d9c3e6: Correct because a shortcut methodology often used by both private equity and real estate managers involves simply citing a multiple of invested capital (MOIC), or money multiple, on total invested capital (which is paid-in capital less management fees and fund expenses). Here, one simply measures the total value of all realized investments and residual asset values (assets that may still be awaiting their ultimate sale) relative to an initial total investment the MOIC ignores the timing of cash flows.
answerFeedback.f090233b-af20-4b7f-9299-859309152e20: Incorrect because the MOIC ignores the timing of cash flows.

choices.itemBody: B. the same as that of Fund 2.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-Alt-Fairborn-10
entry.itemBody: A limited partner in a private equity fund most likely activates a clawback provision if the general partner:

answerFeedback.346921f7-7faf-4a75-b2f4-b5ac4cb325fd: Incorrect because a clawback provision reflects the right of LPs to reclaim part of the GP’s performance fee if a GP ever accrues (or actually pays itself) an incentive fee on gains that are not yet fully realized and then subsequently gives back these gains, an investor is typically able to claw back prior incentive fee accruals and payments. Clawback provisions are usually activated when a GP exits successful deals early on but incurs losses on deals later in the fund’s life. Therefore, a fund that incurs losses early in life is unlikely to activate a clawback provision, even if the fund finishes its life with a positive rate of return.
answerFeedback.7df1b7cb-2ae5-4f05-b9bf-ebebce6c2059: Correct because a clawback provision reflects the right of LPs to reclaim part of the GP’s performance fee if a GP ever accrues (or actually pays itself) an incentive fee on gains that are not yet fully realized and then subsequently gives back these gains, an investor is typically able to claw back prior incentive fee accruals and payments. Clawback provisions are usually activated when a GP exits successful deals early on but incurs losses on deals later in the fund’s life.
answerFeedback.e61065a7-be0f-48be-9a40-42f3a31c2ce7: Incorrect because a clawback provision reflects the right of LPs to reclaim part of the GP’s performance fee if a GP ever accrues (or actually pays itself) an incentive fee on gains that are not yet fully realized and then subsequently gives back these gains, an investor is typically able to claw back prior incentive fee accruals and payments. Clawback provisions are usually activated when a GP exits successful deals early on but incurs losses on deals later in the fund’s life. Therefore, a fund that never records a loss on an investment will not activate a clawback provision.

choices.itemBody: A. exits successful deals early in the fund's life but incurs losses on deals later.
B. exits unsuccessful deals early in the fund's life but generates gains on deals later.
C. exits successful deals early in the fund's life and generates additional gains on deals later.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Horvath-11
entry.itemBody: A stock dividend:

answerFeedback.4c6e7c59-a468-4928-81cf-9ffa42231323: Incorrect because a stock dividend is a type of dividend in which a company distributes additional shares of its common stock (typically, 2%–10% of the shares then outstanding) to shareholders instead of cash. This results in an increase, not a reduction in the number of shares outstanding.
answerFeedback.e559edf2-55c5-409d-a055-b3f843f45596: Incorrect because a stock dividend divides the “pie” (the market value of shareholders’ equity) into smaller pieces without affecting the value of the pie or any shareholder’s proportional ownership in the company.
answerFeedback.f0f52160-0e93-4f98-a55e-f225c3c61ffd: Correct because stock dividends are not relevant for valuation and stock dividends have no economic effect on the company.

choices.itemBody: A. is not relevant for valuation of a company.
B. involves a reduction in the number of shares outstanding.
C. alters the shareholders' proportional ownership in the company.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kassem-28
entry.itemBody: When the investment horizon is less than the Macaulay duration of a bond:

answerFeedback.47a1ecb3-ef73-4c73-b787-74dbc7cc2591: Correct because when the investment horizon is less than the Macaulay duration of the bond, market price risk dominates coupon reinvestment risk.
answerFeedback.6ed318a6-ed5c-414e-b7a1-4412aea3db8a: Incorrect because this is the case when the investment horizon is equal to the Macaulay duration. When the investment horizon is equal to the Macaulay duration of a bond, coupon reinvestment risk offsets market price risk.
answerFeedback.d1c90fc8-7e40-49cc-9a77-85be0c4e8c90: Incorrect because this is the case when the investment horizon is greater than the Macaulay duration. When the investment horizon is greater than the Macaulay duration of a bond, coupon reinvestment risk dominates market price risk.

choices.itemBody: A. coupon reinvestment risk offsets market price risk.
B. market price risk is greater than coupon reinvestment risk.
C. coupon reinvestment risk is greater than market price risk.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-RID-Bailey-Equity-006
entry.itemBody: If a leveraged position is financed at a minimum margin requirement of 55%, the maximum leverage ratio is closest to:

answerFeedback.1da11b04-eb17-4b3d-b273-ec94163bc324: Correct because the maximum leverage ratio associated with a position financed by the minimum margin requirement is one divided by the minimum margin requirement. 100% / 55%  ≈ 1.82.
answerFeedback.6a5eb783-b046-470a-a0c0-34648607d79e: Incorrect because it subtracts the minimum margin requirement from one in the denominator: 100% / (1 – minimum margin requirement). 100% / (1 – 55%) = 100% / (0.45) ≈ 2.22.
answerFeedback.ffb92e00-3922-4a08-8a24-c4f40862709b: Incorrect because it multiplies the total position with 1 plus the minimum margin requirement. 100% x (1 + 0.55) = 1.55.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Chan-09
entry.itemBody: Which type of preference shares can be exchanged into a predetermined number of common shares?

answerFeedback.0978f0df-6193-4db5-bcd3-c1cd3b481dd6: Incorrect because participating preference shares entitle the shareholders to receive the standard preferred dividend plus the opportunity to receive an additional dividend if the company’s profits exceed a pre-specified level.
answerFeedback.cda62555-873d-4b3b-b255-90b64c7dc10c: Incorrect because dividends on cumulative preference shares accrue so that if the company decides not to pay a dividend in one or more periods, the unpaid dividends accrue and must be paid in full before dividends on common shares can be paid.
answerFeedback.d217f866-7659-4c65-81fa-e3cc85116499: Correct because convertible preference shares entitle shareholders to convert their shares into a specified number of common shares.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-PM-Glover-04
entry.itemBody: The mental discomfort that occurs when new information conflicts with previously held beliefs is best described as:

answerFeedback.06403407-b8da-4b33-b71c-d65c78cabdc0: Correct because belief perseverance biases result from the mental discomfort that occurs when new information conflicts with previously held beliefs or cognitions, known as cognitive dissonance.
answerFeedback.8dcf1cf2-c6a1-4a02-bfd8-7b5766d9cb37: Incorrect because regret-aversion bias is an emotional bias in which people tend to avoid making decisions out of fear that the decision will turn out poorly. While regret may be described as a mental discomfort, regret-aversion does not best describe this discomfort, but rather a bias in how individuals respond to actual or anticipated regret.
answerFeedback.8f3f44f4-6b50-4cdf-a27b-d6e2e070c1e2: Incorrect because mental accounting bias refers to mentally dividing money into 'accounts' that influence decisions, even though money is fungible.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kassem-17
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about Canadian bonds:

Bond Coupon Rate Price Years to Maturity
Canadian government benchmark bond 3.0% 101 2
Canadian corporate bond 5.0% 102 2

Assuming annual compounding, the G-spread is closest to:

answerFeedback.27ef8dab-261f-4a43-8a7e-a23f77046954: Incorrect because the yield spread in basis points over an actual or interpolated government bond is known as the G-spread. This answer incorrectly uses the difference between the coupon rates 5.00 – 3.00 = 2.00 or 200 basis points.
answerFeedback.3cad7377-9ca7-4d12-a10f-cc4ca83ffeb1: Incorrect because the yield spread in basis points over an actual or interpolated government bond is known as the G-spread. This answer is only the yield of the Canadian Government Bond. 101 = 3 / (1 + r) + 103 / (1 + r)2. r = 2.48% or 248 basis points.
answerFeedback.839cc51d-f18a-4a55-899b-a6039cb636d7: Correct because the yield spread in basis points over an actual or interpolated government bond is known as the G-spread. Using the data provided, the yield for the Canadian Government Bond is found by 101 = 3 / (1 + r) + 103 / (1 + r)2. r = 2.48%. While the yield on the corporate bond is 102 = 5 / (1 + r) + 105 / (1 + r)2. r = 3.94%. G spread = 3.94 – 2.48 = 1.46 or 146 basis points.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B PM 03KGL
entry.itemBody: The slope of the capital allocation line is the:

answerFeedback.740a76c5-a44b-481f-90a3-7843b9258e32: Incorrect because the market risk premium is the slope of the security market line. The security market line (SML) is a graphical representation of the capital asset pricing model with beta, reflecting systematic risk, on the x-axis and expected return on the y-axis. The slope of this line is the market risk premium, Rm – Rf.
answerFeedback.a7d0c685-102c-41d3-a863-53dbc614f3a3: Correct because the capital allocation line has an intercept of Rf, and a slope of (E(Ri) – Rf)/σi, which is the additional required return for every increment in risk, and is sometimes referred to as the market price of risk.
answerFeedback.e3b08729-4d8f-4dc0-90b1-6a1ee1d8fe5d: Incorrect because the SCL (security characteristic line) is a plot of the excess return of the security on the excess return of the market. Jensen’s alpha is the intercept and the beta is the slope. Furthermore, the beta of the market is 1. The capital allocation line has a slope referred to as the market price of risk.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10478
entry.itemBody: A foundation's spending rules and requirements for the next year are most appropriately specified in the foundation's investment policy statement as a:

answerFeedback.5791546c-b5a4-474c-b83f-b367f1b2021d: Incorrect because the IPS should state what the likely requirements are to withdraw funds from the portfolio. For institutions, it could be spending rules and requirements for endowment funds (and foundations). The IPS should state the time horizon over which the investor is investing. It may be the period over which the portfolio is accumulating before any assets need to be withdrawn. As the spending requirement is determined by the foundation, the withdrawals do not constitute a time horizon constraint but rather a liquidity constraint.
answerFeedback.9fb62f02-5b4f-43f7-8ac7-55837c9f94c2: Incorrect because the IPS should state what the likely requirements are to withdraw funds from the portfolio. For institutions, it could be spending rules and requirements for endowment funds (and foundations). The IPS should state any legal and regulatory restrictions that constrain how the portfolio is invested. As the spending requirement is determined by the foundation, the withdrawals do not constitute a legal or regulatory constraint.
answerFeedback.e788100c-f9ae-47ab-9b3d-0d6200c10c1c: Correct because the IPS should state what the likely requirements are to withdraw funds from the portfolio. For institutions, it could be spending rules and requirements for endowment funds (and foundations), the existence of claims coming due in the case of property and casualty insurance, or benefit payments for pension funds and life insurance companies.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-FI-Hu-02
entry.itemBody: An analyst calculates the duration of a portfolio containing only fixed-rate bonds, callable bonds, and asset-backed securities. Which duration measure is the most appropriate to use?

answerFeedback.b4444b04-a5c5-472b-894f-fb557264cee3: Correct because effective duration is suitable for instruments with uncertain future cash flows like callable bonds, since in brief, a callable bond does not have a well-defined internal rate of return (yield-to-maturity). Therefore, yield duration statistics, such as modified and Macaulay durations, do not apply; effective duration is the appropriate duration measure.
answerFeedback.b780593f-1413-4195-a038-56835c9d5784: Incorrect because modified duration is not suitable for instruments with uncertain future cash flows like callable bonds, since in brief, a callable bond does not have a well-defined internal rate of return (yield-to-maturity). Therefore, yield duration statistics, such as modified and Macaulay durations, do not apply; effective duration is the appropriate duration measure.
answerFeedback.fa961393-bdb7-48b5-ab0e-4e75bf16450c: Incorrect because Macaulay duration is not suitable for instruments with uncertain future cash flows like callable bonds, since in brief, a callable bond does not have a well-defined internal rate of return (yield-to-maturity). Therefore, yield duration statistics, such as modified and Macaulay durations, do not apply; effective duration is the appropriate duration measure.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.01-Equity-Berlinicke-08
entry.itemBody: In contrast to analyzing most companies, an analysis of a bank most likely starts with its:

answerFeedback.4dd4a859-c7f8-4ed8-9946-1c2ff052edbf: Incorrect because for most companies—perhaps with the exception of banks, for which the balance sheet comes first—analysts start by analyzing revenues.
answerFeedback.76b7f731-6e9e-445f-a4c8-d0532c02058c: Correct because for most companies—perhaps with the exception of banks, for which the balance sheet comes first—analysts start by analyzing revenues.
answerFeedback.f4f2fe45-68e8-4747-b6e4-c203d0174cdc: Incorrect because for most companies—perhaps with the exception of banks, for which the balance sheet comes first—analysts start by analyzing revenues.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606074
entry.itemBody: An investment has a 50% probability of returning 12% and a 50% probability of returning 6%. An investor prefers this uncertain investment over a guaranteed return of 10%. This preference most likely indicates that the investor is risk:

answerFeedback.bbdfd5a3-896a-4583-bf8f-8412d0e1135e: Incorrect. A risk-averse person would prefer the guaranteed outcome of 10%.
answerFeedback.c445f7e9-3fe5-48ec-a80c-d763af126ee9: Incorrect. A risk-neutral person would prefer the guaranteed outcome of 10%.
answerFeedback.df969c12-5260-479a-96d0-978797beda88: Correct. The expected value of the uncertain investment is 9% (=50%×12% + 50%×9%), which is less than the guaranteed return of 10%. Only a risk-seeking person would be willing to accept this investment.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Equity-Elkinawy-Young-11
entry.itemBody: With respect to the Gordon growth model, the justified forward P/E is positively related to:

answerFeedback.1d40c72e-a921-4eee-85da-83bce68b8fdf: Correct because the justified forward P/E ratio is: P0/E1 = (D1/E1)/(r – g) = P/(r – g). The equation indicates that the P/E is positively related to the growth rate. As the growth rate increases, the P/E increases.
answerFeedback.5f356e1f-4fd6-42ec-b6f7-2cd8f4149d28: Incorrect because the justified forward P/E ratio is: P0/E1 = (D1/E1)/(r – g) = P/(r – g). The equation indicates that the P/E is inversely related to the required rate of return as the required rate of return increases, the P/E declines.
answerFeedback.8d1b2ccd-3811-4f29-8ef9-1e527cdb762a: Incorrect because the justified forward P/E ratio is: P0/E1 = (D1/E1)/(r – g) = P/(r – g). The equation indicates that the P/E is inversely related to the required rate of return as the required rate of return increases, the P/E declines.

choices.itemBody: B. the required rate of return only.
C. both the growth rate and the required rate of return.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-FRA-Roberts-20
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a company:

ROA 8%
Leverage ratio 1.2
Dividend payout ratio 35%

The sustainable growth rate is closest to:

answerFeedback.54bbdc77-b9da-4c58-8eaf-69cea79972eb: Incorrect because it assumes that the sustainable growth rate = Dividend Payout Ratio × ROE instead of retention rate × ROE. The calculation becomes 35% × (8% × 1.2) = 35% × 9.6% = 0.0336 ≈ 3.4%.
answerFeedback.65d6263a-e3a1-40c1-acb4-62defdfdd5f1: Incorrect because it assumes that the sustainable growth rate = Retention Rate × ROA instead of retention rate × ROE. The calculation becomes (1 – 35%) × 8% = 65% × 8% = 0.052 = 5.2%.
answerFeedback.ace21ee7-87be-4798-8391-7204e6f80144: Correct because the sustainable growth rate = Retention rate × ROE, where ROE = ROA × Leverage, and the retention rate = (1 – Payout Ratio). The calculation becomes (1 – 35%) × (8% × 1.2) = 0.65 × 9.6% = 0.0624 ≈ 6.2%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Alts-Loo-01
entry.itemBody: Alternative investments are most likely characterized by:

answerFeedback.18a91c3d-fd83-4f03-b7b6-392d28a546b4: Incorrect because features that may distinguish alternative investments include typically exhibiting low correlation of returns with more traditional asset classes.
answerFeedback.83c5da9a-6726-4cd1-a92b-8ef047219ff3:
Correct because alternative investments differ from traditional asset classes in
that they involve longer time horizons, unique patterns of cash flows, the use of leverage, illiquid positions, more complex fee structures, different tax and accounting treatment, and so on. Special provisions also exist for the lockup and redemption of capital from investors.
answerFeedback.f297bb45-fc6b-461b-806a-fe8efd0e8c65: Incorrect because fund investment structures for alternative investments differ substantially from traditional public equity and fixed-income fund or ETF investments. For example, alternative funds usually involve less frequent transparency on periodic returns and fund positions versus equity or fixed-income funds.

choices.itemBody: B. more restrictions on redemptions than traditional investments.
C. high correlation of returns with those of traditional investments.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Equity-McDonald-04
entry.itemBody: According to the size effect anomaly:

answerFeedback.196e403f-09a3-4cd6-9fa6-9bc653689082: Incorrect because the size effect results from the observation that equities of small-cap companies tend to outperform equities of large-cap companies on a risk adjusted basis. The outperformance of low P/Es describes the value effect.
answerFeedback.8518f5cf-0c00-49aa-878a-e2ee2d72bf85: Incorrect because the size effect results from the observation that equities of small-cap companies tend to outperform equities of large-cap companies on a risk adjusted basis. The outperformance of equities with above-average dividend yields describes the value effect.
answerFeedback.f3def7b5-2023-4370-9c2c-03f632ff0c07: Correct because the size effect results from the observation that equities of small-cap companies tend to outperform equities of large-cap companies on a risk adjusted basis.

choices.itemBody: A. equities with low P/Es tend to outperform equities with high P/Es.
B. equities with above-average dividend yields tend to outperform equities with below-average dividend yields.
C. equities of small-cap companies tend to outperform equities of large-cap companies on a risk adjusted basis.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kashyap-09
entry.itemBody: A bond issued by a local government is best described as a(n):

answerFeedback.0ea6324e-4eed-44f2-b40c-feebb3ed4ff2: Incorrect because agencies are not local governments. Government agencies are quasi-government entities that issue debt in order to fund the government-sponsored provision of specific public goods or services based on sovereign or local law. This may involve the financing of specific activities promoted by the government or the operation of necessary infrastructure as mandated by law.  For example, the Airport Authority of Hong Kong (AAHK), introduced in an earlier module, is the statutory agency for operating and developing the Hong Kong International Airport. Bonds issued by agencies are called agency bonds.
answerFeedback.57028898-e83e-4a92-9a7f-0cce368d5930: Correct because non-sovereign government authorities (local and regional government authorities) may either issue debt for general purposes, which is repaid from local tax cash flows, or issue debt to fund specific projects or infrastructure, which is repaid from user fees or other cash flows directly derived from the project.
answerFeedback.5e7d4e8a-1dac-4371-9df3-64c0c40afacf: Incorrect because supranational agencies are not local governments. Supranational organizations, such as the World Bank, International Monetary Fund (IMF), and Asian Development Bank (ADB), are created and supported by sovereign governments as member states in pursuit of a common objective, such as fostering economic cooperation and development, promoting trade, or providing financing to emerging economies in pursuit of sustainable growth. Bonds issued by supranational agencies are called supranational bonds.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04705
entry.itemBody: Market efficiency most likely increases with an increase in:

answerFeedback.151e2678-8af2-4ad7-8320-fad4c94fce5b: Incorrect because an increase in the time required to execute trades would limit trading and arbitrage. Obviously, market efficiency is impeded by any limitation on arbitrage resulting from operating inefficiencies, such as difficulties in executing trades in timely manner.
answerFeedback.967eeddd-4630-4507-9b4b-289938eed142: Correct because the number of financial analysts who follow or analyze a security or asset should be positively related to market efficiency. The efficiency of a market is affected by the depth of analyst coverage.
answerFeedback.d53782ca-6e2c-41e0-996d-5ce06d28b1c4: Incorrect because short selling is a form of arbitrage and arbitrage generally promotes efficiency: some market experts argue that restrictions on short selling limit arbitrage trading, which impedes market efficiency. An increase in restrictions on short-selling therefore most likely reduces market efficiency, not increases it.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Young-14
entry.itemBody: A non-recourse residential mortgage loan:

answerFeedback.0e1751da-cecd-47b2-b376-c2830b70c90e: Correct because in a non-recourse loan, the lender can look only to the property to recover the outstanding mortgage balance.
answerFeedback.30666b3c-b890-48f7-8d65-f06ed58bd070: Incorrect because in a non-recourse loan, the lender does not have such a claim and thus can look only to the property to recover the outstanding mortgage balance.
answerFeedback.470535d9-25b6-45cf-a014-1f664ae40094: Incorrect because in a recourse loan (not a non-recourse loan), the lender has a claim against the borrower for the shortfall between the amount of the outstanding mortgage balance and the proceeds received from the sale of the property.

choices.itemBody: A. does not allow the lender to recover the outstanding mortgage balance.
B. only allows the lender to use the property to recover the outstanding mortgage balance.
C. permits the lender to seek recovery of the outstanding mortgage balance from the borrower’s other assets.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Derivs-Augulyte-01
entry.itemBody: A protective put is a derivatives strategy that involves:

answerFeedback.3ebcf704-1a37-45b6-a602-96cd96f3df42: Correct because the strategy of holding the asset and a put is sometimes called a protective put.
answerFeedback.61fbbbb9-788b-4e14-b0c3-c0616050e4b5: Incorrect because the strategy of holding the asset and a put is sometimes called a protective put.
answerFeedback.cb50baaa-f1bb-41db-8e2d-720e239591ad: Incorrect because the strategy of holding the asset and a put is sometimes called a protective put.

choices.itemBody: A. selling a call and buying a put.
B. selling an asset and buying a put.
C. buying an asset and buying a put.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09049
entry.itemBody: The legal owner of loans backing an asset-backed security is most likely the:

answerFeedback.0cf86a7d-5f4e-4444-87c7-e7eea87e5791: Incorrect because although the holder of the ABS has a claim on the loans or assets in the event of a default, the owner of the loans is the SPE. Such a legal entity is referred to as a special purpose entity (SPE) and sometimes also called a special purpose vehicle (SPV) or a special purpose company. The legal form of the SPE varies by jurisdiction, but in almost all cases, the ultimate owner of the loans is legally independent and is considered bankruptcy remote from the seller of the loans. Setting up a separate legal entity ensures that if the originator of the loans, files for bankruptcy, the loans backing the ABS that are issued are secure within the SPE and the creditors have no claim on them.
answerFeedback.61cdebbf-0480-46a7-8f2b-2b57f9a37003: Incorrect because the loan originator sells the loans to the SPE for the purpose of securitization. Such a legal entity is referred to as a special purpose entity (SPE) and sometimes also called a special purpose vehicle (SPV) or a special purpose company. The legal form of the SPE varies by jurisdiction, but in almost all cases, the ultimate owner of the loans is legally independent and is considered bankruptcy remote from the seller of the loans. Setting up a separate legal entity ensures that the originator of the loans, files for bankruptcy, the loans backing the ABS that are issued are secure within the SPE and creditors have no claim on them.
answerFeedback.86a11905-9789-4253-bf88-41214ce86a65: Correct because such a legal entity is referred to as a special purpose entity (SPE) and sometimes also called a special purpose vehicle (SPV) or a special purpose company. The legal form of the SPE varies by jurisdiction, but in almost all cases, the ultimate owner of the loans is legally independent and is considered bankruptcy remote from the seller of the loans. Setting up a separate legal entity ensures that if the originator of the loans, files for bankruptcy, the loans backing the ABS that are issued are secure within the SPE and creditors have no claim on them.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-Alt-Loo-09
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements about limited partnerships is most accurate?

answerFeedback.903f1b8c-6c5b-4cb7-9ea4-9927106ecda9: Incorrect because this should be documented on the side letter instead of the limited partnership agreement. Side letters are side agreements created between the general partner and a certain number of limited partners that exist outside the limited partnership agreement. An example of a clause or detail that may be included in a side letter includes potential additional reporting due to a limited partner's unique circumstances, such as regulatory or tax requirements.
answerFeedback.a84d4128-1269-441c-ac00-2390c3c2381b: Incorrect because the operations and decisions of the fund are controlled solely by the general partner instead of the limited partners. Limited partners play passive roles and are not involved with the management of the fund (although co-investment rights allow for the limited partners to make additional direct investments in the portfolio companies); the operations and decisions of the fund are controlled solely by the general partner.
answerFeedback.fe25df16-7652-4973-b69a-cd2a62cba2aa: Correct because the partnership between the general partner and limited partners is governed by a limited partnership agreement (LPA), a legal document that outlines the rules of the partnership and establishes the framework that ultimately guides the fund’s operations throughout its life.

choices.itemBody: A. The operations and decisions of the fund are controlled solely by the limited partners
B. The partnership between the general partner and the limited partners is governed by a limited partnership agreement
C. Additional regulatory and tax reporting requirements due to a limited partner's unique circumstances are documented in the limited partnership agreement

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kashyap-25
entry.itemBody: With respect to interest rate changes, if an investor's investment time horizon is longer than the time-to-maturity of a bond, coupon reinvestment risk is:

answerFeedback.9677830c-dde3-498c-a3c7-4cf4100c473a: Incorrect because coupon reinvestment risk matters more when the investor has a long-term horizon relative to the time-to-maturity of the bond. For instance, a buy-and-hold investor only has coupon reinvestment risk. Market price risk matters more when the investor has a short-term horizon relative to the time-to-maturity.
answerFeedback.add3d9af-a335-471f-930d-1dc403d79dd3: Incorrect because coupon reinvestment risk matters more when the investor has a long-term horizon relative to the time-to-maturity of the bond. For instance, a buy-and-hold investor only has coupon reinvestment risk. Market price risk matters more when the investor has a short-term horizon relative to the time-to-maturity.
answerFeedback.c140b332-b453-4cf9-a151-d475541d389f: Correct because coupon reinvestment risk matters more when the investor has a long-term horizon relative to the time-to-maturity of the bond. For instance, a buy-and-hold investor only has coupon reinvestment risk. Market price risk matters more when the investor has a short-term horizon relative to the time-to-maturity.

choices.itemBody: B. is equally as important as market risk.

entry.title: ITEM_20170601013
entry.itemBody: A swap in which the investor receives a variable payment in line with market conditions and makes a fixed payment can best be replicated by purchasing a:

answerFeedback.662d80c7-ecc5-43a1-9784-954db8646a46: Incorrect because due to differences in timing, the forward contracts need to be off-market contracts.
answerFeedback.70f83a3b-9c67-41ab-bb35-97d85c26dcc5: Correct because the payment structure is replicated by being long the floating rate bond (i.e., receiving a variable payment) and being short the fixed-rate bond (i.e., making a fixed payment).
answerFeedback.c278da7c-8f00-4e67-9853-12d3346faeec: Incorrect because this strategy does not replicate a swap in which the investor receives a variable payment in line with market conditions and makes a fixed payment.

choices.itemBody: A. floating rate bond financed using a fixed-rate bond.
B. series of forward contracts, each with an initial value of zero.
C. set of long futures contracts which are matched with short forward contracts.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516144
entry.itemBody:
A company’s series B, 8% preferred stock has the following features:

• A par value of $50, and it pays quarterly dividends.

• Its current market value is $35.

• The shares are retractable (at par) with the retraction date set for three years from today.

• Similarly rated preferred issues have an estimated nominal required rate of return of 12%.

• Analysts expect a sustainable growth rate of 4% for the company’s earnings.

The intrinsic value estimate of a share of this preferred issue is closest to:

answerFeedback.9f9682c9-a63d-41ec-ab63-4dc25bf70bf7:
Correct. Because the current market value is well below the retraction price, retraction is likely, and the preferred share will be priced on the basis of its retraction feature.

Quarterly dividend = ($50 × 0.08)/4 = $1 a share

Quarterly required return = 12%/4 = 3%

The value is calculated as follows:

V0 = $1/1.03 + 1/1.032 + . . . $1/1.0312 + $50/1.0312 = $45.02

Or, using a financial calculator:

PMT = $1; N = 12; FV = $50; I = 3%; Compute PV = $45.02.
answerFeedback.a141a118-d1c7-4e81-b8b3-c36368e05d67:
Incorrect. It incorrectly applies the constant growth model to preferred stock valuation.

V0 = 4(1.04)/(0.12 – 0.04) = $52.00
answerFeedback.e284d026-0db6-41cd-9e36-8c4cbdabc9a0: Incorrect. This value is simply the perpetual cash flow model to find a preferred stock’s intrinsic value, which is annual dividend divided by required return = $4/0.12 = $33.33. This calculation fails to incorporate the retractable nature of the shares.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-FI-Agarwal-14
entry.itemBody: The rating agency notching adjustment applied to the subordinated debt rating of speculative grade issuers is most likely:

answerFeedback.38314a7c-210f-4a6c-95e3-ab4bcf2fa324: Incorrect because as a general rule, the higher the senior unsecured rating, the smaller the notching adjustment will be. Speculative grade issuers have lower senior unsecured ratings and hence larger notching adjustments.
answerFeedback.7f6e106e-be66-4b4f-bcde-efc1a8552829: Incorrect because as a general rule, the higher the senior unsecured rating, the smaller the notching adjustment will be. Speculative grade issuers have lower senior unsecured ratings and hence larger notching adjustments.
answerFeedback.b5a00f69-b506-4e89-b125-373ffd7dd217: Correct because as a general rule, the higher the senior unsecured rating, the smaller the notching adjustment will be. Speculative grade issuers have lower senior unsecured ratings and hence larger notching adjustments.

choices.itemBody: A. smaller than that applied to the subordinated debt rating of investment grade issuers.
B. the same as that applied to the subordinated debt rating of investment grade issuers.
C. larger than that applied to the subordinated debt rating of investment grade issuers.
